{"chunk_order_number": 679, "name": "Chunk_679", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it\\nand bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and\\nthey all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor,\\nand got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front\\nwindows\u2014there warn\u2019t none on the side. They held the candle, and took a\\ngood look at me, and all said, \u201cWhy, _he_ ain\u2019t a Shepherdson\u2014no, there\\nain\u2019t any Shepherdson about him.\u201d Then the old man said he hoped I\\nwouldn\u2019t mind being searched for arms, because he didn\u2019t mean no harm\\nby it\u2014it was only to make sure. So he didn\u2019t pry into my pockets, but\\nonly felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right. He told me\\nto make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old\\nlady says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:43Z"}

While I was at it he\\nasked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to\\ntell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods\\nday before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle\\nwent out. I said I didn\u2019t know; I hadn\u2019t heard about it before, no way.", "chunk_order_number": 692, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:45Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 693, "text": "\\\"Well, guess,\\\" he says.", "name": "Chunk 693", "description": "Text chunk from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, guess,\u201d he says.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:45Z"}

{"order_number": 694, "name": "Chunk 694", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "\u201cHow\u2019m I going to guess,\u201d says I, \u201cwhen I never heard tell of it\\nbefore?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 694, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:45Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 698, "text": "\\\"I don\u2019t know where he was,\\\" says I; \\\"where was he?\\\"", "name": "Chunk 698", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "\u201cI don\u2019t know where he was,\u201d says I; \u201cwhere was he?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:46Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 699, "text": "\u201cWhy, he was in the _dark!_ That\u2019s where he was!\u201d", "name": "Chunk 699", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, he was in the _dark!_ That\u2019s where he was!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:46Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 701, "name": "Chunk 701", "description": "Text content passage from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, blame it, it\u2019s a riddle, don\u2019t you see? Say, how long are you\\ngoing to stay here? You got to stay always. We can just have booming\\ntimes\u2014they don\u2019t have no school now. Do you own a dog? I\u2019ve got a\\ndog\u2014and he\u2019ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in. Do\\nyou like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness? You bet\\nI don\u2019t, but ma she makes me. Confound these ole britches! I reckon I\u2019d\\nbetter put \u2019em on, but I\u2019d ruther not, it\u2019s so warm. Are you all ready?\\nAll right. Come along, old hoss.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-27T16:37:46Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 702, "name": "Chunk 702", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk\u2014that is what they\\nhad for me down there, and there ain\u2019t nothing better that ever I\u2019ve\\ncome across yet. Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes,\\nexcept the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women. They\\nall smoked and talked, and I eat and talked. The young women had quilts\\naround them, and their hair down their backs. They all asked me\\nquestions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living\\non a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann\\nrun off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went\\nto hunt them and he warn\u2019t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and\\nthen there warn\u2019t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just\\ntrimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I\\ntook what there was left, because the farm didn\u2019t belong to us, and\\nstarted up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was\\nhow I c...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:46Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 711, "name": "Chunk 711", "description": "Text passage from chapter XVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too. I hadn\u2019t\\nseen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so\\nmuch style. It didn\u2019t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a\\nwooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same\\nas houses in town. There warn\u2019t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a\\nbed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them. There was a big\\nfireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean\\nand red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick;\\nsometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call\\nSpanish-brown, same as they do in town. They had big brass dog-irons\\nthat could hold up a saw-log. There was a clock on the middle of the\\nmantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the\\nglass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you\\ncould see the pendulum swinging behind it. It was beautiful to hear\\nthat clock t...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:47Z"}

There warn\u2019t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a\\nbed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them. There was a big\\nfireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean\\nand red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick;\\nsometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call\\nSpanish-brown, same as they do in town. They had big brass dog-irons\\nthat could hold up a saw-log. There was a clock on the middle of the\\nmantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the\\nglass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you\\ncould see the pendulum swinging behind it. {"chunk_order_number": 712, "text": "Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made\\nout of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy. By one of the\\nparrots was a cat made of crockery, and a crockery dog by the other;\\nand when you pressed down on them they squeaked, but didn\u2019t open their\\nmouths nor look different nor interested. They squeaked through\\nunderneath. There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out\\nbehind those things. On the table in the middle of the room was a kind\\nof a lovely crockery basket that had apples and oranges and peaches and\\ngrapes piled up in it, which was much redder and yellower and prettier\\nthan real ones is, but they warn\u2019t real because you could see where\\npieces had got chipped off and showed the white chalk, or whatever it\\nwas, underneath.", "name": "Chunk 712", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made\\nout of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy. {"chunk_order_number": 713, "name": "Chunk 713", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "This table had a cover made out of beautiful oilcloth, with a red and\\nblue spread-eagle painted on it, and a painted border all around. It\\ncome all the way from Philadelphia, they said. There was some books,\\ntoo, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table. One was a\\nbig family Bible full of pictures. One was Pilgrim\u2019s Progress, about a\\nman that left his family, it didn\u2019t say why. I read considerable in it\\nnow and then. The statements was interesting, but tough. Another was\\nFriendship\u2019s Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn\u2019t\\nread the poetry. Another was Henry Clay\u2019s Speeches, and another was Dr.\\nGunn\u2019s Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body\\nwas sick or dead. There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books. And\\nthere was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too\u2014not bagged\\ndown in the middle and busted, like an old basket.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-19T16:58:36Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 714, "name": "Chunk 714", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "They had pictures hung on the walls\u2014mainly Washingtons and Lafayettes,\\nand battles, and Highland Marys, and one called \u201cSigning the\\nDeclaration.\u201d There was some that they called crayons, which one of the\\ndaughters which was dead made her own self when she was only fifteen\\nyears old. They was different from any pictures I ever see\\nbefore\u2014blacker, mostly, than is common. One was a woman in a slim black\\ndress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in\\nthe middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a\\nblack veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and\\nvery wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on\\na tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other\\nhand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule,\\nand underneath the picture it said \u201cShall I Never See Thee More Alas.\u201d\\nAnother one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to\\nthe top of her h...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:48Z"}

One was a woman in a slim black\\ndress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in\\nthe middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a\\nblack veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and\\nvery wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on\\na tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other\\nhand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule,\\nand underneath the picture it said \u201cShall I Never See Thee More Alas.\u201d\\nAnother one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to\\nthe top of her h...", "chunk_order_number": 714, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:48Z"}

{"order_number": 715, "content": "This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the _Presbyterian Observer_, and write poetry after them out of her own head. It was very good poetry. {"chunk_order_number": 723, "name": "Chunk 723", "description": "Text content passage from Chapter XVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "If Emmeline Grangerford could make poetry like that before she was\\nfourteen, there ain\u2019t no telling what she could a done by-and-by. Buck\\nsaid she could rattle off poetry like nothing. She didn\u2019t ever have to\\nstop to think. He said she would slap down a line, and if she couldn\u2019t\\nfind anything to rhyme with it would just scratch it out and slap down\\nanother one, and go ahead. She warn\u2019t particular; she could write about\\nanything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful.\\nEvery time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be\\non hand with her \u201ctribute\u201d before he was cold. She called them\\ntributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline,\\nthen the undertaker\u2014the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but\\nonce, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person\u2019s name,\\nwhich was Whistler. She warn\u2019t ever the same after that; she never\\ncomplained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long. Poor\\nthing, many\u2019s the...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:48Z"}

{"order_number": 724, "name": "Chunk 724", "description": "Text passage from chapter XVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVII.", "chunk": "Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on\\nthe windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines\\nall down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink. There was a little\\nold piano, too, that had tin pans in it, I reckon, and nothing was ever\\nso lovely as to hear the young ladies sing \u201cThe Last Link is Broken\u201d\\nand play \u201cThe Battle of Prague\u201d on it. The walls of all the rooms was\\nplastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was\\nwhitewashed on the outside.", "chunk_order_number": 724, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:49Z"}

Col. His forehead was high, and his hair was black and\\nstraight and hung to his shoulders. His hands was long and thin, and\\nevery day of his life he put on a clean shirt and a full suit from head\\nto foo...", "chunk_order_number": 726, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:49Z"}

{"order_number": 727, "name": "Chunk 727", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "When him and the old lady come down in the morning all the family got\\nup out of their chairs and give them good-day, and didn\u2019t set down\\nagain till they had set down. Then Tom and Bob went to the sideboard\\nwhere the decanter was, and mixed a glass of bitters and handed it to\\nhim, and he held it in his hand and waited till Tom\u2019s and Bob\u2019s was\\nmixed, and then they bowed and said, \u201cOur duty to you, sir, and madam;\u201d\\nand _they_ bowed the least bit in the world and said thank you, and so\\nthey drank, all three, and Bob and Tom poured a spoonful of water on\\nthe sugar and the mite of whisky or apple brandy in the bottom of their\\ntumblers, and give it to me and Buck, and we drank to the old people\\ntoo.", "chunk_order_number": 727, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 733, "name": "Chunk 733", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "The old gentleman owned a lot of farms and over a hundred niggers.\\nSometimes a stack of people would come there, horseback, from ten or\\nfifteen mile around, and stay five or six days, and have such\\njunketings round about and on the river, and dances and picnics in the\\nwoods daytimes, and balls at the house nights. These people was mostly\\nkinfolks of the family. The men brought their guns with them. It was a\\nhandsome lot of quality, I tell you.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T15:18:32Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 734, "name": "Chunk 734", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "There was another clan of aristocracy around there\u2014five or six\\nfamilies\u2014mostly of the name of Shepherdson. They was as high-toned and\\nwell born and rich and grand as the tribe of Grangerfords. The\\nShepherdsons and Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing, which\\nwas about two mile above our house; so sometimes when I went up there\\nwith a lot of our folks I used to see a lot of the Shepherdsons there\\non their fine horses.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:30:00Z"}

{"text": "\\\"Quick! Jump for the woods!\\\"", "chunk_order_number": 736, "name": "Chunk 736", "description": "Text chunk from chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cQuick! Jump for the woods!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:50Z"}

{"order_number": 737, "text": "We done it, and then peeped down the woods through the leaves. Pretty soon a splendid young man come galloping down the road, setting his horse easy and looking like a soldier. He had his gun across his pommel. I had seen him before. It was young Harney Shepherdson. I heard Buck\u2019s gun go off at my ear, and Harney\u2019s hat tumbled off from his head. He grabbed his gun and rode straight to the place where we was hid. But we didn\u2019t wait. We started through the woods on a run. The woods warn\u2019t thick, so I looked over my shoulder to dodge the bullet, and twice I seen Harney cover Buck with his gun; and then he rode away the way he come\u2014to get his hat, I reckon, but I couldn\u2019t see. We never stopped running till we got home. {"chunk_order_number": 740, "name": "Chunk 740", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "Miss Charlotte she held her head up like a queen while Buck was telling\\nhis tale, and her nostrils spread and her eyes snapped. {"order_number": 741, "text": "Soon as I could get Buck down by the corn-cribs under the trees by ourselves, I says:", "name": "Chunk 741", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "Soon as I could get Buck down by the corn-cribs under the trees by\\nourselves, I says:", "chunk_order_number": 741, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:50Z"}

{"text": "\\\"Did you want to kill him, Buck?\\\"", "name": "Chunk 742", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cDid you want to kill him, Buck?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 742, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:50Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 750, "name": "Chunk 750", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cNever heard of it before\u2014tell me about it.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:51Z"}

{"name": "Man 1", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell,\u201d says Buck, \u201ca feud is this way. A man has a quarrel with\\nanother man, and kills him; then that other man\u2019s brother kills _him;_\\nthen the other brothers, on both sides, goes for one another; then the\\n_cousins_ chip in\u2014and by-and-by everybody\u2019s killed off, and there ain\u2019t\\nno more feud. But it\u2019s kind of slow, and takes a long time.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 751, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:52Z"}

{"name": "Brother", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell,\u201d says Buck, \u201ca feud is this way. But it\u2019s kind of slow, and takes a long time.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 751, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:52Z"}

{"text": "\\\"Has this one been going on long, Buck?\\\"", "name": "Chunk 752", "description": "Text segment from chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cHas this one been going on long, Buck?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 752, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:52Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 753, "name": "Chunk 753", "description": "Text passage from chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I should _reckon!_ It started thirty year ago, or som\u2019ers along\\nthere. There was trouble \u2019bout something, and then a lawsuit to settle\\nit; and the suit went agin one of the men, and so he up and shot the\\nman that won the suit\u2014which he would naturally do, of course. Anybody\\nwould.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:52Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 760", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cHas there been many killed, Buck?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 760, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:54Z"}

{"name": "Pa", "description": "Character in the story.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes; right smart chance of funerals. But they don\u2019t always kill. Pa\u2019s\\ngot a few buckshot in him; but he don\u2019t mind it \u2019cuz he don\u2019t weigh\\nmuch, anyway. Bob\u2019s been carved up some with a bowie, and Tom\u2019s been\\nhurt once or twice.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 761, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:54Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 763, "name": "Chunk 763", "description": "Text passage from chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes; we got one and they got one. \u2019Bout three months ago my cousin\\nBud, fourteen year old, was riding through the woods on t\u2019other side of\\nthe river, and didn\u2019t have no weapon with him, which was blame\u2019\\nfoolishness, and in a lonesome place he hears a horse a-coming behind\\nhim, and sees old Baldy Shepherdson a-linkin\u2019 after him with his gun in\\nhis hand and his white hair a-flying in the wind; and \u2019stead of jumping\\noff and taking to the brush, Bud \u2019lowed he could out-run him; so they\\nhad it, nip and tuck, for five mile or more, the old man a-gaining all\\nthe time; so at last Bud seen it warn\u2019t any use, so he stopped and\\nfaced around so as to have the bullet holes in front, you know, and the\\nold man he rode up and shot him down. But he didn\u2019t git much chance to\\nenjoy his luck, for inside of a week our folks laid _him_ out.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T12:34:56Z"}

But he didn\u2019t git much chance to\\nenjoy his luck, for inside of a week our folks laid _him_ out.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 763, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T12:34:56Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 764, "text": "\\\"I reckon that old man was a coward, Buck.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 764", "description": "Text passage from the book", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cI reckon that old man was a coward, Buck.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T16:37:54Z"}

{"name": "woodpile", "description": "Location", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cI reckon he _warn\u2019t_ a coward. Not by a blame\u2019 sight. There ain\u2019t a\\ncoward amongst them Shepherdsons\u2014not a one. And there ain\u2019t no cowards\\namongst the Grangerfords either. Why, that old man kep\u2019 up his end in a\\nfight one day for half an hour against three Grangerfords, and come out\\nwinner. They was all a-horseback; he lit off of his horse and got\\nbehind a little woodpile, and kep\u2019 his horse before him to stop the\\nbullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and capered around\\nthe old man, and peppered away at him, and he peppered away at them.\\nHim and his horse both went home pretty leaky and crippled, but the\\nGrangerfords had to be _fetched_ home\u2014and one of \u2019em was dead, and\\nanother died the next day. No, sir; if a body\u2019s out hunting for cowards\\nhe don\u2019t want to fool away any time amongst them Shepherdsons, becuz\\nthey don\u2019t breed any of that _kind_.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 765, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:55Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 766, "name": "Chunk 766", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "Next Sunday we all went to church, about three mile, everybody\\na-horseback. The men took their guns along, so did Buck, and kept them\\nbetween their knees or stood them handy against the wall. The\\nShepherdsons done the same. It was pretty ornery preaching\u2014all about\\nbrotherly love, and such-like tiresomeness; but everybody said it was a\\ngood sermon, and they all talked it over going home, and had such a\\npowerful lot to say about faith and good works and free grace and\\npreforeordestination, and I don\u2019t know what all, that it did seem to me\\nto be one of the roughest Sundays I had run across yet.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:55Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 767, "text": "About an hour after dinner everybody was dozing around, some in their\\nchairs and some in their rooms, and it got to be pretty dull. Buck and\\na dog was stretched out on the grass in the sun sound asleep. I went up\\nto our room, and judged I would take a nap myself. I found that sweet\\nMiss Sophia standing in her door, which was next to ours, and she took\\nme in her room and shut the door very soft, and asked me if I liked\\nher, and I said I did; and she asked me if I would do something for her\\nand not tell anybody, and I said I would. Then she said she\u2019d forgot\\nher Testament, and left it in the seat at church between two other\\nbooks, and would I slip out quiet and go there and fetch it to her, and\\nnot say nothing to nobody. I said I would. So I slid out and slipped\\noff up the road, and there warn\u2019t anybody at the church, except maybe a\\nhog or two, for there warn\u2019t any lock on the door, and hogs likes a\\npuncheon floor in summer-time because it\u2019s cool. {"name": "paper", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "Says I to myself, something\u2019s up; it ain\u2019t natural for a girl to be in\\nsuch a sweat about a Testament. So I give it a shake, and out drops a\\nlittle piece of paper with \u201c_Half-past two_\u201d wrote on it with a pencil.\\nI ransacked it, but couldn\u2019t find anything else. I couldn\u2019t make\\nanything out of that, so I put the paper in the book again, and when I\\ngot home and upstairs there was Miss Sophia in her door waiting for me.\\nShe pulled me in and shut the door; then she looked in the Testament\\ntill she found the paper, and as soon as she read it she looked glad;\\nand before a body could think she grabbed me and give me a squeeze, and\\nsaid I was the best boy in the world, and not to tell anybody. {"order_number": 777, "name": "Chunk 777", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cI got hurt a little, en couldn\u2019t swim fas\u2019, so I wuz a considable ways\\nbehine you towards de las\u2019; when you landed I reck\u2019ned I could ketch up\\nwid you on de lan\u2019 \u2019dout havin\u2019 to shout at you, but when I see dat\\nhouse I begin to go slow. I \u2019uz off too fur to hear what dey say to\\nyou\u2014I wuz \u2019fraid o\u2019 de dogs; but when it \u2019uz all quiet agin, I knowed\\nyou\u2019s in de house, so I struck out for de woods to wait for day. Early\\nin de mawnin\u2019 some er de niggers come along, gwyne to de fields, en dey\\ntuk me en showed me dis place, whah de dogs can\u2019t track me on accounts\\no\u2019 de water, en dey brings me truck to eat every night, en tells me how\\nyou\u2019s a-gitt\u2019n along.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 777, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:56Z"}

{"order_number": 783, "name": "Chunk 783", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cNo, she warn\u2019t. She was tore up a good deal\u2014one en\u2019 of her was; but\\ndey warn\u2019t no great harm done, on\u2019y our traps was mos\u2019 all los\u2019. Ef we\\nhadn\u2019 dive\u2019 so deep en swum so fur under water, en de night hadn\u2019 ben\\nso dark, en we warn\u2019t so sk\u2019yerd, en ben sich punkin-heads, as de\\nsayin\u2019 is, we\u2019d a seed de raf\u2019. But it\u2019s jis\u2019 as well we didn\u2019t, \u2019kase\\nnow she\u2019s all fixed up agin mos\u2019 as good as new, en we\u2019s got a new lot\\no\u2019 stuff, in de place o\u2019 what \u2019uz los\u2019.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 783, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-20T10:37:57Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 784, "text": "\u201cWhy, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim\u2014did you catch her?\u201d", "name": "chunk_784", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim\u2014did you catch her?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:57Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 785, "name": "Chunk 785", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cHow I gwyne to ketch her en I out in de woods? No; some er de niggers\\nfoun\u2019 her ketched on a snag along heah in de ben\u2019, en dey hid her in a\\ncrick \u2019mongst de willows, en dey wuz so much jawin\u2019 \u2019bout which un \u2019um\\nshe b\u2019long to de mos\u2019 dat I come to heah \u2019bout it pooty soon, so I ups\\nen settles de trouble by tellin\u2019 \u2019um she don\u2019t b\u2019long to none uv um,\\nbut to you en me; en I ast \u2019m if dey gwyne to grab a young white\\ngenlman\u2019s propaty, en git a hid\u2019n for it? Den I gin \u2019m ten cents\\napiece, en dey \u2019uz mighty well satisfied, en wisht some mo\u2019 raf\u2019s \u2019ud\\ncome along en make \u2019m rich agin. Dey\u2019s mighty good to me, dese niggers\\nis, en whatever I wants \u2019m to do fur me, I doan\u2019 have to ast \u2019m twice,\\nhoney. Dat Jack\u2019s a good nigger, en pooty smart.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-11-20T10:15:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 786, "name": "Chunk 786", "description": "\\\\\"Yes, he is. He ain\u2019t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and he\u2019d show me a lot of water-moccasins. If anything happens _he_ ain\u2019t mixed up in it. He can say he never seen us together, and it\u2019ll be the truth.\\\\\"", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes, he is. He ain\u2019t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and\\nhe\u2019d show me a lot of water-moccasins. If anything happens _he_ ain\u2019t\\nmixed up in it. He can say he never seen us together, and it\u2019ll be the\\ntruth.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:57Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 787, "name": "Chunk 787", "description": "I don\u2019t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I\u2019ll cut it pretty short. I waked up about dawn, and was a-going to turn over and go to sleep again, when I noticed how still it was\u2014didn\u2019t seem to be anybody stirring. That warn\u2019t usual. Next I noticed that Buck was up and gone. Well, I gets up, a-wondering, and goes down stairs\u2014nobody around; everything as still as a mouse. Just the same outside. Thinks I, what does it mean? Down by the wood-pile I comes across my Jack, and says:", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "I don\u2019t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I\u2019ll cut it\\npretty short. {"order_number": 791, "name": "Chunk 791", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cNo,\u201d says I, \u201cI don\u2019t.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 791, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:58Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 792, "name": "Chunk 792", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, den, Miss Sophia\u2019s run off! \u2019deed she has. She run off in de\\nnight some time\u2014nobody don\u2019t know jis\u2019 when; run off to get married to\\ndat young Harney Shepherdson, you know\u2014leastways, so dey \u2019spec. De\\nfambly foun\u2019 it out \u2019bout half an hour ago\u2014maybe a little mo\u2019\u2014en\u2019 I\\n_tell_ you dey warn\u2019t no time los\u2019. Sich another hurryin\u2019 up guns en\\nhosses _you_ never see! De women folks has gone for to stir up de\\nrelations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de\\nriver road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him \u2019fo\u2019 he kin\\ngit acrost de river wid Miss Sophia. I reck\u2019n dey\u2019s gwyne to be mighty\\nrough times.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

Sich another hurryin\u2019 up guns en\\nhosses _you_ never see! De women folks has gone for to stir up de\\nrelations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de\\nriver road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him \u2019fo\u2019 he kin\\ngit acrost de river wid Miss Sophia. I reck\u2019n dey\u2019s gwyne to be mighty\\nrough times.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 792, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 795, "text": "I took up the river road as hard as I could put. By-and-by I begin to\\nhear guns a good ways off. When I come in sight of the log store and\\nthe woodpile where the steamboats lands, I worked along under the trees\\nand brush till I got to a good place, and then I clumb up into the\\nforks of a cottonwood that was out of reach, and watched. There was a\\nwood-rank four foot high a little ways in front of the tree, and first\\nI was going to hide behind that; but maybe it was luckier I didn\u2019t.", "name": "Chunk 795", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "I took up the river road as hard as I could put. {"chunk_order_number": 796, "text": "There was four or five men cavorting around on their horses in the open place before the log store, cussing and yelling, and trying to get at a couple of young chaps that was behind the wood-rank alongside of the steamboat landing; but they couldn\u2019t come it. {"chunk_order_number": 797, "name": "Chunk 797", "description": "Text passage from chapter XVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling. They started\\nriding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady\\nbead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle. All\\nthe men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started\\nto carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the\\nrun. They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed.\\nThen the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after\\nthem. They gained on the boys, but it didn\u2019t do no good, the boys had\\ntoo good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my\\ntree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men\\nagain. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap\\nabout nineteen years old.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-27T16:37:59Z"}

{"text": "The men ripped around awhile, and then rode away. As soon as they was out of sight I sung out to Buck and told him. He didn\u2019t know what to make of my voice coming out of the tree at first. He was awful surprised. He told me to watch out sharp and let him know when the men come in sight again; said they was up to some devilment or other\u2014wouldn\u2019t be gone long. I wished I was out of that tree, but I dasn\u2019t come down. Buck begun to cry and rip, and \u2019lowed that him and his cousin Joe (that was the other young chap) would make up for this day yet. He said his father and his two brothers was killed, and two or three of the enemy. Said the Shepherdsons laid for them in ambush. Buck said his father and brothers ought to waited for their relations\u2014the Shepherdsons was too strong for them. I asked him what was become of young Harney and Miss Sophia. He said they\u2019d got across the river and was safe. {"name": "Chunk 799", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "All of a sudden, bang! bang! bang! goes three or four guns\u2014the men had\\nslipped around through the woods and come in from behind without their\\nhorses! The boys jumped for the river\u2014both of them hurt\u2014and as they\\nswum down the current the men run along the bank shooting at them and\\nsinging out, \u201cKill them, kill them!\u201d It made me so sick I most fell out\\nof the tree. I ain\u2019t a-going to tell _all_ that happened\u2014it would make\\nme sick again if I was to do that. I wished I hadn\u2019t ever come ashore\\nthat night to see such things. I ain\u2019t ever going to get shut of\\nthem\u2014lots of times I dream about them.", "chunk_order_number": 799, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 800, "name": "Chunk 800", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down.\\nSometimes I heard guns away off in the woods; and twice I seen little\\ngangs of men gallop past the log store with guns; so I reckoned the\\ntrouble was still a-going on. I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my\\nmind I wouldn\u2019t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I\\nwas to blame, somehow. I judged that that piece of paper meant that\\nMiss Sophia was to meet Harney somewheres at half-past two and run off;\\nand I judged I ought to told her father about that paper and the\\ncurious way she acted, and then maybe he would a locked her up, and\\nthis awful mess wouldn\u2019t ever happened.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:37:59Z"}

I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my\\nmind I wouldn\u2019t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I\\nwas to blame, somehow. {"chunk_order_number": 801, "text": "When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could. {"chunk_order_number": 802, "text": "It was just dark now. I never went near the house, but struck through\\nthe woods and made for the swamp. Jim warn\u2019t on his island, so I\\ntramped off in a hurry for the crick, and crowded through the willows,\\nred-hot to jump aboard and get out of that awful country. The raft was\\ngone! My souls, but I was scared! I couldn\u2019t get my breath for most a\\nminute. Then I raised a yell. A voice not twenty-five foot from me\\nsays:", "name": "Chunk 802", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "It was just dark now. {"chunk_order_number": 805, "text": "\u201cLaws bless you, chile, I \u2019uz right down sho\u2019 you\u2019s dead agin. Jack\u2019s been heah; he say he reck\u2019n you\u2019s ben shot, kase you didn\u2019 come home no mo\u2019; so I\u2019s jes\u2019 dis minute a startin\u2019 de raf\u2019 down towards de mouf er de crick, so\u2019s to be all ready for to shove out en leave soon as Jack comes agin en tells me for certain you _is_ dead. {"order_number": 807, "name": "Chunk 807", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cAll right\u2014that\u2019s mighty good; they won\u2019t find me, and they\u2019ll think\\nI\u2019ve been killed, and floated down the river\u2014there\u2019s something up there\\nthat\u2019ll help them think so\u2014so don\u2019t you lose no time, Jim, but just\\nshove off for the big water as fast as ever you can.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 807, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 808", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XVIII.", "chunk": "I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the\\nmiddle of the Mississippi. Then we hung up our signal lantern, and\\njudged that we was free and safe once more. I hadn\u2019t had a bite to eat\\nsince yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk,\\nand pork and cabbage and greens\u2014there ain\u2019t nothing in the world so\\ngood when it\u2019s cooked right\u2014and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and\\nhad a good time. I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so\\nwas Jim to get away from the swamp. We said there warn\u2019t no home like a\\nraft, after all. Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a\\nraft don\u2019t. You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.", "chunk_order_number": 808, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chapter_order_number": 809, "name": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum\\nby, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely. Here is the way we\\nput in the time. It was a monstrous big river down there\u2014sometimes a\\nmile and a half wide; we run nights, and laid up and hid daytimes; soon\\nas night was most gone we stopped navigating and tied up\u2014nearly always\\nin the dead water under a tow-head; and then cut young cottonwoods and\\nwillows, and hid the raft with them. Then we set out the lines. Next we\\nslid into the river and had a swim, so as to freshen up and cool off;\\nthen we set down on the sandy bottom where the water was about knee\\ndeep, and watched the daylight come. Not a sound anywheres\u2014perfectly\\nstill\u2014just like the whole world was asleep, only sometimes the\\nbullfrogs a-cluttering, maybe. The first thing to see, looking away\\nover the water, was a kind of dull line\u2014that was the woods on t\u2019other\\nside; you couldn\u2019t make nothing else out; then a pale place in the sky;\\nthen mor...", "chunk_order_number": 809, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 810, "name": "Chunk 810", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "A little smoke couldn\u2019t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off\\nof the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch\\nthe lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by\\nlazy off to sleep. Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and\\nmaybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the\\nother side you couldn\u2019t tell nothing about her only whether she was a\\nstern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldn\u2019t be\\nnothing to hear nor nothing to see\u2014just solid lonesomeness. Next you\u2019d\\nsee a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it\\nchopping, because they\u2019re most always doing it on a raft; you\u2019d see the\\naxe flash and come down\u2014you don\u2019t hear nothing; you see that axe go up\\nagain, and by the time it\u2019s above the man\u2019s head then you hear the\\n_k\u2019chunk!_\u2014it had took all that time to come over the water. So we\\nwould put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness. Once\\nthere ...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 812, "text": "Soon as it was night out we shoved; when we got her out to about the\\nmiddle we let her alone, and let her float wherever the current wanted\\nher to; then we lit the pipes, and dangled our legs in the water, and\\ntalked about all kinds of things\u2014we was always naked, day and night,\\nwhenever the mosquitoes would let us\u2014the new clothes Buck\u2019s folks made\\nfor me was too good to be comfortable, and besides I didn\u2019t go much on\\nclothes, nohow.", "name": "Chunk 812", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Soon as it was night out we shoved; when we got her out to about the\\nmiddle we let her alone, and let her float wherever the current wanted\\nher to; then we lit the pipes, and dangled our legs in the water, and\\ntalked about all kinds of things\u2014we was always naked, day and night,\\nwhenever the mosquitoes would let us\u2014the new clothes Buck\u2019s folks made\\nfor me was too good to be comfortable, and besides I didn\u2019t go much on\\nclothes, nohow.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:01Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 813, "name": "Chunk 813", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX. of ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Sometimes we\u2019d have that whole river all to ourselves for the longest\\ntime. Yonder was the banks and the islands, across the water; and maybe\\na spark\u2014which was a candle in a cabin window; and sometimes on the\\nwater you could see a spark or two\u2014on a raft or a scow, you know; and\\nmaybe you could hear a fiddle or a song coming over from one of them\\ncrafts. It\u2019s lovely to live on a raft. We had the sky up there, all\\nspeckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at\\nthem, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened.\\nJim he allowed they was made, but I allowed they happened; I judged it\\nwould have took too long to _make_ so many. Jim said the moon could a\\n_laid_ them; well, that looked kind of reasonable, so I didn\u2019t say\\nnothing against it, because I\u2019ve seen a frog lay most as many, so of\\ncourse it could be done. We used to watch the stars that fell, too, and\\nsee them streak down. Jim allowed they\u2019d got spoiled and was hove out\\nof the nest.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-10T14:20:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 814, "name": "Chunk 814", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XIX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Once or twice of a night we would see a steamboat slipping along in the\\ndark, and now and then she would belch a whole world of sparks up out\\nof her chimbleys, and they would rain down in the river and look awful\\npretty; then she would turn a corner and her lights would wink out and\\nher powwow shut off and leave the river still again; and by-and-by her\\nwaves would get to us, a long time after she was gone, and joggle the\\nraft a bit, and after that you wouldn\u2019t hear nothing for you couldn\u2019t\\ntell how long, except maybe frogs or something.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T13:45:22Z"}

{"name": "sparks", "description": "Sparks emitted from a steamboat", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Once or twice of a night we would see a steamboat slipping along in the\\ndark, and now and then she would belch a whole world of sparks up out\\nof her chimbleys, and they would rain down in the river and look awful\\npretty; then she would turn a corner and her lights would wink out and\\nher powwow shut off and leave the river still again; and by-and-by her\\nwaves would get to us, a long time after she was gone, and joggle the\\nraft a bit, and after that you wouldn\u2019t hear nothing for you couldn\u2019t\\ntell how long, except maybe frogs or something.", "chunk_order_number": 814, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T13:45:22Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 815, "name": "Chunk 815", "description": "Text content passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "After midnight the people on shore went to bed, and then for two or\\nthree hours the shores was black\u2014no more sparks in the cabin windows.\\nThese sparks was our clock\u2014the first one that showed again meant\\nmorning was coming, so we hunted a place to hide and tie up right away.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:01Z"}

{"name": "midnight", "description": "When people on shore went to bed", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "After midnight the people on shore went to bed, and then for two or\\nthree hours the shores was black\u2014no more sparks in the cabin windows.\\nThese sparks was our clock\u2014the first one that showed again meant\\nmorning was coming, so we hunted a place to hide and tie up right away.", "chunk_order_number": 815, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:01Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 816", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to\\nthe main shore\u2014it was only two hundred yards\u2014and paddled about a mile\\nup a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn\u2019t get some\\nberries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath\\ncrossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as\\ntight as they could foot it. I thought I was a goner, for whenever\\nanybody was after anybody I judged it was _me_\u2014or maybe Jim. I was\\nabout to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me\\nthen, and sung out and begged me to save their lives\u2014said they hadn\u2019t\\nbeen doing nothing, and was being chased for it\u2014said there was men and\\ndogs a-coming. They wanted to jump right in, but I says:", "chunk_order_number": 816, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"name": "Chunk 817", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cDon\u2019t you do it. I don\u2019t hear the dogs and horses yet; you\u2019ve got time\\nto crowd through the brush and get up the crick a little ways; then you\\ntake to the water and wade down to me and get in\u2014that\u2019ll throw the dogs\\noff the scent.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 817, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"name": "Chunk_818", "description": "They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head, and in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away off, shouting. We heard them come along towards the crick, but couldn\u2019t see them; they seemed to stop and fool around a while; then, as we got further and further away all the time, we couldn\u2019t hardly hear them at all; by the time we had left a mile of woods behind us and struck the river, everything was quiet, and we paddled over to the tow-head and hid in the cottonwoods and was safe.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head,\\nand in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away\\noff, shouting. {"chunk_order_number": 819, "name": "Chunk 819", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head\\nand very gray whiskers. He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a\\ngreasy blue woollen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed\\ninto his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses\u2014no, he only had one. He had\\nan old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over\\nhis arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:01Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 822, "name": "Chunk 822", "description": "Text content passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I\u2019d been selling an article to take the tartar off the teeth\u2014and\\nit does take it off, too, and generly the enamel along with it\u2014but I\\nstayed about one night longer than I ought to, and was just in the act\\nof sliding out when I ran across you on the trail this side of town,\\nand you told me they were coming, and begged me to help you to get off.\\nSo I told you I was expecting trouble myself, and would scatter out\\n_with_ you. That\u2019s the whole yarn\u2014what\u2019s yourn?", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:02Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 823, "content": "\u201cWell, I\u2019d ben a-runnin\u2019 a little temperance revival thar, \u2019bout a\\nweek, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was\\nmakin\u2019 it mighty warm for the rummies, I _tell_ you, and takin\u2019 as much\\nas five or six dollars a night\u2014ten cents a head, children and niggers\\nfree\u2014and business a-growin\u2019 all the time, when somehow or another a\\nlittle report got around last night that I had a way of puttin\u2019 in my\\ntime with a private jug on the sly. A nigger rousted me out this\\nmornin\u2019, and told me the people was getherin\u2019 on the quiet with their\\ndogs and horses, and they\u2019d be along pretty soon and give me \u2019bout half\\nan hour\u2019s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me\\nthey\u2019d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure. I didn\u2019t wait\\nfor no breakfast\u2014I warn\u2019t hungry.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 823", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I\u2019d ben a-runnin\u2019 a little temperance revival thar, \u2019bout a\\nweek, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was\\nmakin\u2019 it mighty warm for the rummies, I _tell_ you, and takin\u2019 as much\\nas five or six dollars a night\u2014ten cents a head, children and niggers\\nfree\u2014and business a-growin\u2019 all the time, when somehow or another a\\nlittle report got around last night that I had a way of puttin\u2019 in my\\ntime with a private jug on the sly. A nigger rousted me out this\\nmornin\u2019, and told me the people was getherin\u2019 on the quiet with their\\ndogs and horses, and they\u2019d be along pretty soon and give me \u2019bout half\\nan hour\u2019s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me\\nthey\u2019d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure. I didn\u2019t wait\\nfor no breakfast\u2014I warn\u2019t hungry.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:02Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 826, "text": "\u201cJour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor\u2014tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there\u2019s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes\u2014oh, I do lots of things\u2014most anything that comes handy, so it ain\u2019t work. {"chunk_order_number": 827, "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time. Layin\u2019 on o\u2019 hands is my best holt\u2014for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k\u2019n tell a fortune pretty good when I\u2019ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me. {"chunk_order_number": 831, "text": "\\\"To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be\\ndegraded down into such company.\\\" And he begun to wipe the corner of\\nhis eye with a rag.", "name": "Chunk 831", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cTo think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be\\ndegraded down into such company.\u201d And he begun to wipe the corner of\\nhis eye with a rag.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:04Z"}

{"order_number": 832, "text": "\\\"Dern your skin, ain\u2019t the company good enough for you?\\\" says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.", "name": "Chunk 832", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cDern your skin, ain\u2019t the company good enough for you?\u201d says the\\nbaldhead, pretty pert and uppish.", "chunk_order_number": 832, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 833, "name": "Chunk 833", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cYes, it _is_ good enough for me; it\u2019s as good as I deserve; for who\\nfetched me so low when I was so high? _I_ did myself. I don\u2019t blame\\n_you_, gentlemen\u2014far from it; I don\u2019t blame anybody. I deserve it all.\\nLet the cold world do its worst; one thing I know\u2014there\u2019s a grave\\nsomewhere for me. The world may go on just as it\u2019s always done, and\\ntake everything from me\u2014loved ones, property, everything; but it can\u2019t\\ntake that. Some day I\u2019ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor\\nbroken heart will be at rest.\u201d He went on a-wiping.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:04Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 840, "text": "Jim\u2019s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too.\\nThen the baldhead says: \u201cNo! you can\u2019t mean it?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 840", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Jim\u2019s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too.\\nThen the baldhead says: \u201cNo! you can\u2019t mean it?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 841, "name": "Chunk 841", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cYes. My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled\\nto this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure\\nair of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father\\ndying about the same time. The second son of the late duke seized the\\ntitles and estates\u2014the infant real duke was ignored. I am the lineal\\ndescendant of that infant\u2014I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and\\nhere am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised\\nby the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the\\ncompanionship of felons on a raft!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T16:38:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 842, "name": "Chunk 842", "description": "Text content passage from Chapter XIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but\\nhe said it warn\u2019t much use, he couldn\u2019t be much comforted; said if we\\nwas a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most\\nanything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. He said we\\nought to bow when we spoke to him, and say \u201cYour Grace,\u201d or \u201cMy Lord,\u201d\\nor \u201cYour Lordship\u201d\u2014and he wouldn\u2019t mind it if we called him plain\\n\u201cBridgewater,\u201d which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and\\none of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for\\nhim he wanted done.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 858, "name": "Chunk_858", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cTrouble has done it, Bilgewater, trouble has done it; trouble has\\nbrung these gray hairs and this premature balditude. {"order_number": 859, "name": "Chunk 859", "description": "Text content from Chapter 19", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "Well, he cried and took on so that me and Jim didn\u2019t know hardly what\\nto do, we was so sorry\u2014and so glad and proud we\u2019d got him with us, too.\\nSo we set in, like we done before with the duke, and tried to comfort\\n_him_. But he said it warn\u2019t no use, nothing but to be dead and done\\nwith it all could do him any good; though he said it often made him\\nfeel easier and better for a while if people treated him according to\\nhis rights, and got down on one knee to speak to him, and always called\\nhim \u201cYour Majesty,\u201d and waited on him first at meals, and didn\u2019t set\\ndown in his presence till he asked them. So Jim and me set to\\nmajestying him, and doing this and that and t\u2019other for him, and\\nstanding up till he told us we might set down. This done him heaps of\\ngood, and so he got cheerful and comfortable. But the duke kind of\\nsoured on him, and didn\u2019t look a bit satisfied with the way things was\\ngoing; still, the king acted real friendly towards him, and said the\\nduke\u2019s great-grandf...", "chunk_order_number": 859, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:08Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 860", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "\u201cLike as not we got to be together a blamed long time on this h-yer\\nraft, Bilgewater, and so what\u2019s the use o\u2019 your bein\u2019 sour? It\u2019ll only\\nmake things oncomfortable. It ain\u2019t my fault I warn\u2019t born a duke, it\\nain\u2019t your fault you warn\u2019t born a king\u2014so what\u2019s the use to worry?\\nMake the best o\u2019 things the way you find \u2019em, says I\u2014that\u2019s my motto.\\nThis ain\u2019t no bad thing that we\u2019ve struck here\u2014plenty grub and an easy\\nlife\u2014come, give us your hand, Duke, and le\u2019s all be friends.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 860, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T15:45:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 861, "text": "The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it. It took\\naway all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because\\nit would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the\\nraft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody\\nto be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.", "name": "Chunk 861", "chapter": "CHAPTER XIX.", "chunk": "The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it. {"chunk_order_number": 862, "name": "Chunk 862", "description": "It didn\u2019t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warn\u2019t no\\nkings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds. But I\\nnever said nothing, never let on; kept it to myself; it\u2019s the best way;\\nthen you don\u2019t have no quarrels, and don\u2019t get into no trouble. If they\\nwanted us to call them kings and dukes, I hadn\u2019t no objections, \u2019long\\nas it would keep peace in the family; and it warn\u2019t no use to tell Jim,\\nso I didn\u2019t tell him. {"text": "\u201cGoodness sakes, would a runaway nigger run _south?_\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 864, "name": "Chunk 864", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201cGoodness sakes, would a runaway nigger run _south?_\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:09Z"}

{"content": "No, they allowed he wouldn\u2019t. {"chunk_order_number": 869, "name": "Chunk 869", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat\\nlightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was\\nbeginning to shiver\u2014it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see\\nthat. So the duke and the king went to overhauling our wigwam, to see\\nwhat the beds was like. My bed was a straw tick better than Jim\u2019s,\\nwhich was a corn-shuck tick; there\u2019s always cobs around about in a\\nshuck tick, and they poke into you and hurt; and when you roll over the\\ndry shucks sound like you was rolling over in a pile of dead leaves; it\\nmakes such a rustling that you wake up. Well, the duke allowed he would\\ntake my bed; but the king allowed he wouldn\u2019t. He says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:09Z"}

{"name": "misfortune", "description": "The state of being unfortunate", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201c\u2019Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of\\noppression. {"order_number": 873, "name": "Chunk 873", "description": "Text segment from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The king told us to stand\\nwell out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we\\ngot a long ways below the town. We come in sight of the little bunch of\\nlights by-and-by\u2014that was the town, you know\u2014and slid by, about a half\\na mile out, all right. When we was three-quarters of a mile below we\\nhoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o\u2019clock it come on to rain\\nand blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us\\nto both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the\\nduke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night. It was my\\nwatch below till twelve, but I wouldn\u2019t a turned in anyway if I\u2019d had a\\nbed, because a body don\u2019t see such a storm as that every day in the\\nweek, not by a long sight. My souls, how the wind did scream along! {"chunk_order_number": 874, "name": "Chunk 874", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time,\\nso Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was\\nalways mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but\\nthe king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn\u2019t no\\nshow for me; so I laid outside\u2014I didn\u2019t mind the rain, because it was\\nwarm, and the waves warn\u2019t running so high now. About two they come up\\nagain, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind,\\nbecause he reckoned they warn\u2019t high enough yet to do any harm; but he\\nwas mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a\\nregular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing.\\nHe was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:10Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 875, "name": "Chunk 875", "description": "Text chunk from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by\\nthe storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that\\nshowed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters\\nfor the day.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:10Z"}

{"name": "watch", "description": "Object mentioned in the chunk", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by\\nthe storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that\\nshowed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters\\nfor the day.", "chunk_order_number": 875, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:10Z"}

{"order_number": 876, "name": "Chunk 876", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him\\nand the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game. Then they got\\ntired of it, and allowed they would \u201clay out a campaign,\u201d as they\\ncalled it. The duke went down into his carpet-bag, and fetched up a lot\\nof little printed bills and read them out loud. One bill said, \u201cThe\\ncelebrated Dr. Armand de Montalban, of Paris,\u201d would \u201clecture on the\\nScience of Phrenology\u201d at such and such a place, on the blank day of\\nblank, at ten cents admission, and \u201cfurnish charts of character at\\ntwenty-five cents apiece.\u201d The duke said that was _him_. In another\\nbill he was the \u201cworld-renowned Shakespearian tragedian, Garrick the\\nYounger, of Drury Lane, London.\u201d In other bills he had a lot of other\\nnames and done other wonderful things, like finding water and gold with\\na \u201cdivining-rod,\u201d \u201cdissipating witch spells,\u201d and so on. By-and-by he\\nsays:", "chunk_order_number": 876, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:10Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 880, "name": "Chunk 880", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201cI\u2019m in, up to the hub, for anything that will pay, Bilgewater; but,\\nyou see, I don\u2019t know nothing about play-actin\u2019, and hain\u2019t ever seen\\nmuch of it. {"chunk_order_number": 884, "name": "Chunk 884", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201cBut if Juliet\u2019s such a young gal, duke, my peeled head and my white\\nwhiskers is goin\u2019 to look oncommon odd on her, maybe.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 885, "name": "Chunk 885", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201cNo, don\u2019t you worry; these country jakes won\u2019t ever think of that.\\nBesides, you know, you\u2019ll be in costume, and that makes all the\\ndifference in the world; Juliet\u2019s in a balcony, enjoying the moonlight\\nbefore she goes to bed, and she\u2019s got on her night-gown and her ruffled\\nnightcap. Here are the costumes for the parts.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

Here are the costumes for the parts.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 885, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 886, "name": "Chunk 886", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "He got out two or three curtain-calico suits, which he said was\\nmeedyevil armor for Richard III. and t\u2019other chap, and a long white\\ncotton nightshirt and a ruffled nightcap to match. The king was\\nsatisfied; so the duke got out his book and read the parts over in the\\nmost splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same\\ntime, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the\\nking and told him to get his part by heart.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 887, "name": "Chunk 887", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "There was a little one-horse town about three mile down the bend, and\\nafter dinner the duke said he had ciphered out his idea about how to\\nrun in daylight without it being dangersome for Jim; so he allowed he\\nwould go down to the town and fix that thing. The king allowed he would\\ngo, too, and see if he couldn\u2019t strike something. We was out of coffee,\\nso Jim said I better go along with them in the canoe and get some.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

{"name": "sick nigger", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "When we got there there warn\u2019t nobody stirring; streets empty, and\\nperfectly dead and still, like Sunday. We found a sick nigger sunning\\nhimself in a back yard, and he said everybody that warn\u2019t too young or\\ntoo sick or too old was gone to camp-meeting, about two mile back in\\nthe woods. The king got the directions, and allowed he\u2019d go and work\\nthat camp-meeting for all it was worth, and I might go, too.", "chunk_order_number": 888, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 889, "name": "Chunk 889", "description": "Text passage from chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "The duke said what he was after was a printing-office. We found it; a\\nlittle bit of a concern, up over a carpenter shop\u2014carpenters and\\nprinters all gone to the meeting, and no doors locked. It was a dirty,\\nlittered-up place, and had ink marks, and handbills with pictures of\\nhorses and runaway niggers on them, all over the walls. The duke shed\\nhis coat and said he was all right now. So me and the king lit out for\\nthe camp-meeting.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-26T12:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 890, "name": "Chunk_890", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most\\nawful hot day. There was as much as a thousand people there from twenty\\nmile around. The woods was full of teams and wagons, hitched\\neverywheres, feeding out of the wagon-troughs and stomping to keep off\\nthe flies. There was sheds made out of poles and roofed over with\\nbranches, where they had lemonade and gingerbread to sell, and piles of\\nwatermelons and green corn and such-like truck.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 891, "name": "Chunk 891", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "The preaching was going on under the same kinds of sheds, only they was\\nbigger and held crowds of people. The benches was made out of outside\\nslabs of logs, with holes bored in the round side to drive sticks into\\nfor legs. They didn\u2019t have no backs. The preachers had high platforms\\nto stand on at one end of the sheds. The women had on sun-bonnets; and\\nsome had linsey-woolsey frocks, some gingham ones, and a few of the\\nyoung ones had on calico. Some of the young men was barefooted, and\\nsome of the children didn\u2019t have on any clothes but just a tow-linen\\nshirt. Some of the old women was knitting, and some of the young folks\\nwas courting on the sly.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-08-03T10:15:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 892, "name": "The first shed we come to the preacher was lining out a hymn. He lined out two lines, everybody sung it, and it was kind of grand to hear it, there was so many of them and they done it in such a rousing way; then he lined out two more for them to sing\u2014and so on. The people woke up more and more, and sung louder and louder; and towards the end some begun to groan, and some begun to shout. Then the preacher begun to preach, and begun in earnest, too; and went weaving first to one side of the platform and then the other, and then a-leaning down over the front of it, with his arms and his body going all the time, and shouting his words out with all his might; and every now and then he would hold up his Bible and spread it open, and kind of pass it around this way and that, shouting, \u201cIt\u2019s the brazen serpent in the wilderness! Look upon it and live!\u201d And people would shout out, \u201cGlory!\u2014A-a-_men!_\u201d And so he went on, and the people groaning and crying and saying amen:", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "The first shed we come to the preacher was lining out a hymn. {"chunk_order_number": 893, "name": "Chunk 893", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "\u201cOh, come to the mourners\u2019 bench! come, black with sin! (_amen!_) come,\\nsick and sore! (_amen!_) come, lame and halt and blind! (_amen!_) come,\\npore and needy, sunk in shame! (_a-a-men!_) come, all that\u2019s worn and\\nsoiled and suffering!\u2014come with a broken spirit! come with a contrite\\nheart! come in your rags and sin and dirt! the waters that cleanse is\\nfree, the door of heaven stands open\u2014oh, enter in and be at rest!\u201d\\n(_a-a-men!_ _glory, glory hallelujah!_)", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:38:12Z"}

{"name": "Chunk_894", "chapter": "CHAPTER XX.", "chunk": "And so on. You couldn\u2019t make out what the preacher said any more, on\\naccount of the shouting and crying. Folks got up everywheres in the\\ncrowd, and worked their way just by main strength to the mourners\u2019\\nbench, with the tears running down their faces; and when all the\\nmourners had got up there to the front benches in a crowd, they sung\\nand shouted and flung themselves down on the straw, just crazy and\\nwild.", "chunk_order_number": 894, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T15:18:39Z"}
