{"chunk_order_number": 1763, "name": "Chunk_1763", "description": "\u201cWhy, to saw Jim\u2019s leg off,\u201d he says.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, to saw Jim\u2019s leg off,\u201d he says.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-26T15:30:00Z"}

{"order_number": 1764, "text": "\\\"Good land!\\\" I says; \\\"why, there ain't _no_ necessity for it. And what\\nwould you want to saw his leg off for, anyway?\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1764", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cGood land!\u201d I says; \u201cwhy, there ain\u2019t _no_ necessity for it. And what\\nwould you want to saw his leg off for, anyway?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1764, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:05Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1765, "name": "Chunk_1765", "description": "\u201cWell, some of the best authorities has done it. They couldn\u2019t get the\\nchain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved. And a leg would\\nbe better still. But we got to let that go. There ain\u2019t necessity\\nenough in this case; and, besides, Jim\u2019s a nigger, and wouldn\u2019t\\nunderstand the reasons for it, and how it\u2019s the custom in Europe; so\\nwe\u2019ll let it go. But there\u2019s one thing\u2014he can have a rope ladder; we\\ncan tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough. And we\\ncan send it to him in a pie; it\u2019s mostly done that way. And I\u2019ve et\\nworse pies.\u201d", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, some of the best authorities has done it. They couldn\u2019t get the\\nchain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved. And a leg would\\nbe better still. But we got to let that go. There ain\u2019t necessity\\nenough in this case; and, besides, Jim\u2019s a nigger, and wouldn\u2019t\\nunderstand the reasons for it, and how it\u2019s the custom in Europe; so\\nwe\u2019ll let it go. But there\u2019s one thing\u2014he can have a rope ladder; we\\ncan tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough. And we\\ncan send it to him in a pie; it\u2019s mostly done that way. And I\u2019ve et\\nworse pies.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:05Z"}

{"name": "pie", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, some of the best authorities has done it. They couldn\u2019t get the\\nchain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved. And a leg would\\nbe better still. But we got to let that go. There ain\u2019t necessity\\nenough in this case; and, besides, Jim\u2019s a nigger, and wouldn\u2019t\\nunderstand the reasons for it, and how it\u2019s the custom in Europe; so\\nwe\u2019ll let it go. But there\u2019s one thing\u2014he can have a rope ladder; we\\ncan tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough. And we\\ncan send it to him in a pie; it\u2019s mostly done that way. {"chunk_order_number": 1766, "text": "\\\"Why, Tom Sawyer, how you talk,\\\" I says; \\\"Jim ain\u2019t got no use for a rope ladder.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1766", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Tom Sawyer, how you talk,\u201d I says; \u201cJim ain\u2019t got no use for a\\nrope ladder.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T15:30:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1767, "text": "\u201cHe _has_ got use for it. How _you_ talk, you better say; you don\u2019t\\nknow nothing about it. He\u2019s _got_ to have a rope ladder; they all do.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1767", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cHe _has_ got use for it. How _you_ talk, you better say; you don\u2019t\\nknow nothing about it. He\u2019s _got_ to have a rope ladder; they all do.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1768, "text": "\u201cWhat in the nation can he _do_ with it?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1768", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhat in the nation can he _do_ with it?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1769, "name": "Chunk 1769", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201c_Do_ with it? He can hide it in his bed, can\u2019t he?\u201d That\u2019s what they\\nall do; and _he\u2019s_ got to, too. Huck, you don\u2019t ever seem to want to do\\nanything that\u2019s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all\\nthe time. S\u2019pose he _don\u2019t_ do nothing with it? ain\u2019t it there in his\\nbed, for a clew, after he\u2019s gone? and don\u2019t you reckon they\u2019ll want\\nclews? Of course they will. And you wouldn\u2019t leave them any? That would\\nbe a _pretty_ howdy-do, _wouldn\u2019t_ it! I never heard of such a thing.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1770, "name": "Chunk 1770", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell,\u201d I says, \u201cif it\u2019s in the regulations, and he\u2019s got to have it,\\nall right, let him have it; because I don\u2019t wish to go back on no\\nregulations; but there\u2019s one thing, Tom Sawyer\u2014if we go to tearing up\\nour sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we\u2019re going to get into trouble\\nwith Aunt Sally, just as sure as you\u2019re born. Now, the way I look at\\nit, a hickry-bark ladder don\u2019t cost nothing, and don\u2019t waste nothing,\\nand is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as\\nany rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain\u2019t had no\\nexperience, and so _he_ don\u2019t care what kind of a\u2014\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T12:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1771, "name": "Chunk 1771", "description": "Text passage in CHAPTER XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cOh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I\u2019d keep\\nstill\u2014that\u2019s what _I\u2019d_ do. Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping\\nby a hickry-bark ladder? Why, it\u2019s perfectly ridiculous.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 1772", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, all right, Tom, fix it your own way; but if you\u2019ll take my\\nadvice, you\u2019ll let me borrow a sheet off of the clothesline.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1772, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"order_number": 1775, "text": "\u201cWhat do we want of a shirt, Tom?\u201d", "name": "Chunk_1775", "description": "Text Segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhat do we want of a shirt, Tom?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1775, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1776, "name": "Chunk 1776", "description": "\u201cWant it for Jim to keep a journal on.\u201d", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWant it for Jim to keep a journal on.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"name": "journal", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWant it for Jim to keep a journal on.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1776, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"order_number": 1777, "name": "Chunk 1777", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cJournal your granny\u2014_Jim_ can\u2019t write.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1777, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1778, "name": "Chunk 1778", "description": "Text passage from chapter XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cS\u2019pose he _can\u2019t_ write\u2014he can make marks on the shirt, can\u2019t he, if\\nwe make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron\\nbarrel-hoop?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T14:57:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1779, "text": "\u201cWhy, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1779", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better\\none; and quicker, too.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"name": "goose", "description": "Object mentioned in the chunk", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better\\none; and quicker, too.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1779, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:06Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1780, "name": "Chunk 1780", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201c_Prisoners_ don\u2019t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull\\npens out of, you muggins. They _always_ make their pens out of the\\nhardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or\\nsomething like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them\\nweeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because\\nthey\u2019ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall. _They_ wouldn\u2019t use a\\ngoose-quill if they had it. It ain\u2019t regular.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:19:28Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1781, "text": "\u201cWell, then, what\u2019ll we make him the ink out of?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1781", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then, what\u2019ll we make him the ink out of?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:07Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 1782", "description": "\u201cMany makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that\u2019s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood. The\\nIron Mask always done that, and it\u2019s a blame\u2019 good way, too.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1782, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:07Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1792, "name": "Chunk 1792", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "Along during the morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt off of\\nthe clothes-line; and I found an old sack and put them in it, and we\\nwent down and got the fox-fire, and put that in too. I called it\\nborrowing, because that was what pap always called it; but Tom said it\\nwarn\u2019t borrowing, it was stealing. He said we was representing\\nprisoners; and prisoners don\u2019t care how they get a thing so they get\\nit, and nobody don\u2019t blame them for it, either. It ain\u2019t no crime in a\\nprisoner to steal the thing he needs to get away with, Tom said; it\u2019s\\nhis right; and so, as long as we was representing a prisoner, we had a\\nperfect right to steal anything on this place we had the least use for\\nto get ourselves out of prison with. He said if we warn\u2019t prisoners it\\nwould be a very different thing, and nobody but a mean, ornery person\\nwould steal when he warn\u2019t a prisoner. So we allowed we would steal\\neverything there was that come handy. {"order_number": 1801, "name": "Chunk 1801", "description": "Text chunk from CHAPTER XXXV of ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cHuck Finn, did you _ever_ hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels,\\nand all the modern conveniences in his wardrobe to dig himself out\\nwith? Now I want to ask you\u2014if you got any reasonableness in you at\\nall\u2014what kind of a show would _that_ give him to be a hero? Why, they\\nmight as well lend him the key and done with it. Picks and shovels\u2014why,\\nthey wouldn\u2019t furnish \u2019em to a king.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1801, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T00:00:00Z"}

{"name": "picks and shovels", "description": "Tools mentioned in the chunk", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cHuck Finn, did you _ever_ hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels,\\nand all the modern conveniences in his wardrobe to dig himself out\\nwith? Now I want to ask you\u2014if you got any reasonableness in you at\\nall\u2014what kind of a show would _that_ give him to be a hero? Why, they\\nmight as well lend him the key and done with it. Picks and shovels\u2014why,\\nthey wouldn\u2019t furnish \u2019em to a king.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1801, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T00:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1802, "text": "\\\"Well, then,\\\" I says, \\\"if we don\u2019t want the picks and shovels, what do\\nwe want?\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1802", "description": "Text chunk from CHAPTER XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then,\u201d I says, \u201cif we don\u2019t want the picks and shovels, what do\\nwe want?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1803, "text": "\u201cA couple of case-knives.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1803", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cA couple of case-knives.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"name": "case-knives", "description": "Case-knives", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cA couple of case-knives.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1803, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1804, "text": "\u201cTo dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1804", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cTo dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"order_number": 1805, "text": "\\\"Yes.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1805", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cYes.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1805, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"order_number": 1806, "text": "\u201cConfound it, it\u2019s foolish, Tom.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1806", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cConfound it, it\u2019s foolish, Tom.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1806, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:09Z"}

{"order_number": 1807, "name": "Chunk 1807", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cIt don\u2019t make no difference how foolish it is, it\u2019s the _right_\\nway\u2014and it\u2019s the regular way. And there ain\u2019t no _other_ way, that ever\\n_I_ heard of, and I\u2019ve read all the books that gives any information\\nabout these things. They always dig out with a case-knife\u2014and not\\nthrough dirt, mind you; generly it\u2019s through solid rock. And it takes\\nthem weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever. Why, look at one\\nof them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the\\nharbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was _he_\\nat it, you reckon?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1807, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:10Z"}

Why, look at one\\nof them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the\\nharbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was _he_\\nat it, you reckon?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1807, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:10Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1809, "text": "\u201cWell, guess.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1809", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, guess.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"name": "Time", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cHow long will it take, Tom?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1816, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:10Z"}

{"name": "1817", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, we can\u2019t resk being as long as we ought to, because it mayn\u2019t\\ntake very long for Uncle Silas to hear from down there by New Orleans.\\nHe\u2019ll hear Jim ain\u2019t from there. Then his next move will be to\\nadvertise Jim, or something like that. So we can\u2019t resk being as long\\ndigging him out as we ought to. By rights I reckon we ought to be a\\ncouple of years; but we can\u2019t. Things being so uncertain, what I\\nrecommend is this: that we really dig right in, as quick as we can; and\\nafter that, we can _let on_, to ourselves, that we was at it\\nthirty-seven years. Then we can snatch him out and rush him away the\\nfirst time there\u2019s an alarm. Yes, I reckon that\u2019ll be the best way.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1817, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-26T10:16:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1818, "text": "\u201cNow, there\u2019s _sense_ in that,\u201d I says. \u201cLetting on don\u2019t cost nothing; letting on ain\u2019t no trouble; and if it\u2019s any object, I don\u2019t mind letting on we was at it a hundred and fifty year. It wouldn\u2019t strain me none, after I got my hand in. So I\u2019ll mosey along now, and smouch a couple of case-knives.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1818", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXV.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cNow, there\u2019s _sense_ in that,\u201d I says. \u201cLetting on don\u2019t cost nothing;\\nletting on ain\u2019t no trouble; and if it\u2019s any object, I don\u2019t mind\\nletting on we was at it a hundred and fifty year. It wouldn\u2019t strain me\\nnone, after I got my hand in. So I\u2019ll mosey along now, and smouch a\\ncouple of case-knives.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:10Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1819, "content": "\\\"Smouch three,\\\" he says; \\\"we want one to make a saw out of.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1819", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cSmouch three,\u201d he says; \u201cwe want one to make a saw out of.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1820, "name": "Chunk 1820", "description": "Chunk of text from Chapter XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cTom, if it ain\u2019t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,\u201d I says,\\n\u201cthere\u2019s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the\\nweather-boarding behind the smoke-house.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:11Z"}

{"name": "rusty saw-blade", "description": "Old rusty saw-blade", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "\u201cTom, if it ain\u2019t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,\u201d I says,\\n\u201cthere\u2019s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the\\nweather-boarding behind the smoke-house.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1820, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:11Z"}

{"order_number": 1821, "name": "Chunk 1821", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXV", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXV.", "chunk": "He looked kind of weary and discouraged-like, and says:", "chunk_order_number": 1821, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T16:40:11Z"}

{"name": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "description": "Chapter XXXVI of ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the\\nlightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our\\npile of fox-fire, and went to work. We cleared everything out of the\\nway, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log. Tom\\nsaid he was right behind Jim\u2019s bed now, and we\u2019d dig in under it, and\\nwhen we got through there couldn\u2019t nobody in the cabin ever know there\\nwas any hole there, because Jim\u2019s counter-pin hung down most to the\\nground, and you\u2019d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole.\\nSo we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we\\nwas dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn\u2019t see\\nwe\u2019d done anything hardly. At last I says:", "chunk_order_number": 1823, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-27T14:10:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1823, "name": "Chunk 1823", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXVI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the\\nlightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our\\npile of fox-fire, and went to work. We cleared everything out of the\\nway, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log. Tom\\nsaid he was right behind Jim\u2019s bed now, and we\u2019d dig in under it, and\\nwhen we got through there couldn\u2019t nobody in the cabin ever know there\\nwas any hole there, because Jim\u2019s counter-pin hung down most to the\\nground, and you\u2019d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole.\\nSo we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we\\nwas dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn\u2019t see\\nwe\u2019d done anything hardly. At last I says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-27T14:10:11Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1824, "text": "\u201cThis ain\u2019t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job,\\nTom Sawyer.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1824", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cThis ain\u2019t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job,\\nTom Sawyer.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"name": "Job Duration", "description": "The length of the task", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cThis ain\u2019t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job,\\nTom Sawyer.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1824, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1825, "text": "He never said nothing. But he sighed, and pretty soon he stopped digging, and then for a good little while I knowed that he was thinking. But he sighed, and pretty soon he stopped\\ndigging, and then for a good little while I knowed that he was\\nthinking. Then he says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1826, "name": "Chunk 1826", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cIt ain\u2019t no use, Huck, it ain\u2019t a-going to work. If we was prisoners\\nit would, because then we\u2019d have as many years as we wanted, and no\\nhurry; and we wouldn\u2019t get but a few minutes to dig, every day, while\\nthey was changing watches, and so our hands wouldn\u2019t get blistered, and\\nwe could keep it up right along, year in and year out, and do it right,\\nand the way it ought to be done. But _we_ can\u2019t fool along; we got to\\nrush; we ain\u2019t got no time to spare. If we was to put in another night\\nthis way we\u2019d have to knock off for a week to let our hands get\\nwell\u2014couldn\u2019t touch a case-knife with them sooner.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"name": "Frustration", "description": "A state of feeling resulting from failure to achieve one's aims", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cIt ain\u2019t no use, Huck, it ain\u2019t a-going to work. If we was prisoners\\nit would, because then we\u2019d have as many years as we wanted, and no\\nhurry; and we wouldn\u2019t get but a few minutes to dig, every day, while\\nthey was changing watches, and so our hands wouldn\u2019t get blistered, and\\nwe could keep it up right along, year in and year out, and do it right,\\nand the way it ought to be done. But _we_ can\u2019t fool along; we got to\\nrush; we ain\u2019t got no time to spare. If we was to put in another night\\nthis way we\u2019d have to knock off for a week to let our hands get\\nwell\u2014couldn\u2019t touch a case-knife with them sooner.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1826, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"content": "\u201cWell, then, what we going to do, Tom?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1827, "name": "Chunk 1827", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then, what we going to do, Tom?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1828, "text": "\u201cI\u2019ll tell you. It ain\u2019t right, and it ain\u2019t moral, and I wouldn\u2019t like\\nit to get out; but there ain\u2019t only just the one way: we got to dig him\\nout with the picks, and _let on_ it\u2019s case-knives.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1828", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cI\u2019ll tell you. It ain\u2019t right, and it ain\u2019t moral, and I wouldn\u2019t like\\nit to get out; but there ain\u2019t only just the one way: we got to dig him\\nout with the picks, and _let on_ it\u2019s case-knives.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"order_number": 1829, "text": "\\\"_Now_ you\u2019re _talking!_\u201d I says; \u201cyour head gets leveler and leveler all the time, Tom Sawyer,\u201d I says. \u201cPicks is the thing, moral or no moral; and as for me, I don\u2019t care shucks for the morality of it, nohow. When I start in to steal a nigger, or a watermelon, or a Sunday-school book, I ain\u2019t no ways particular how it\u2019s done so it\u2019s done. What I want is my nigger; or what I want is my watermelon; or what I want is my Sunday-school book; and if a pick\u2019s the handiest thing, that\u2019s the thing I\u2019m a-going to dig that nigger or that watermelon or that Sunday-school book out with; and I don\u2019t give a dead rat what the authorities thinks about it nuther.\\\"", "name": "Chunk_1829", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201c_Now_ you\u2019re _talking!_\u201d I says; \u201cyour head gets leveler and leveler\\nall the time, Tom Sawyer,\u201d I says. \u201cPicks is the thing, moral or no\\nmoral; and as for me, I don\u2019t care shucks for the morality of it,\\nnohow. When I start in to steal a nigger, or a watermelon, or a\\nSunday-school book, I ain\u2019t no ways particular how it\u2019s done so it\u2019s\\ndone. What I want is my nigger; or what I want is my watermelon; or\\nwhat I want is my Sunday-school book; and if a pick\u2019s the handiest\\nthing, that\u2019s the thing I\u2019m a-going to dig that nigger or that\\nwatermelon or that Sunday-school book out with; and I don\u2019t give a dead\\nrat what the authorities thinks about it nuther.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1829, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:12Z"}

{"name": "Chunk_1830", "description": "\u201cWell,\u201d he says, \u201cthere\u2019s excuse for picks and letting-on in a case\\nlike this; if it warn\u2019t so, I wouldn\u2019t approve of it, nor I wouldn\u2019t\\nstand by and see the rules broke\u2014because right is right, and wrong is\\nwrong, and a body ain\u2019t got no business doing wrong when he ain\u2019t\\nignorant and knows better. It might answer for _you_ to dig Jim out\\nwith a pick, _without_ any letting on, because you don\u2019t know no\\nbetter; but it wouldn\u2019t for me, because I do know better. {"name": "Chunk 1839", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "Next day Tom stole a pewter spoon and a brass candlestick in the house,\\nfor to make some pens for Jim out of, and six tallow candles; and I\\nhung around the nigger cabins and laid for a chance, and stole three\\ntin plates. {"name": "Chunk 1843", "description": "Text segment from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "That night we went down the lightning-rod a little after ten, and took\\none of the candles along, and listened under the window-hole, and heard\\nJim snoring; so we pitched it in, and it didn\u2019t wake him. Then we\\nwhirled in with the pick and shovel, and in about two hours and a half\\nthe job was done. We crept in under Jim\u2019s bed and into the cabin, and\\npawed around and found the candle and lit it, and stood over Jim\\nawhile, and found him looking hearty and healthy, and then we woke him\\nup gentle and gradual. He was so glad to see us he most cried; and\\ncalled us honey, and all the pet names he could think of; and was for\\nhaving us hunt up a cold-chisel to cut the chain off of his leg with\\nright away, and clearing out without losing any time. But Tom he showed\\nhim how unregular it would be, and set down and told him all about our\\nplans, and how we could alter them in a minute any time there was an\\nalarm; and not to be the least afraid, because we would see he got\\naway, _sure_...", "chunk_order_number": 1843, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 1846, "name": "Chunk 1846", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "So he told Jim how we\u2019d have to smuggle in the rope-ladder pie and\\nother large things by Nat, the nigger that fed him, and he must be on\\nthe lookout, and not be surprised, and not let Nat see him open them;\\nand we would put small things in uncle\u2019s coat-pockets and he must steal\\nthem out; and we would tie things to aunt\u2019s apron-strings or put them\\nin her apron-pocket, if we got a chance; and told him what they would\\nbe and what they was for. And told him how to keep a journal on the\\nshirt with his blood, and all that. He told him everything. Jim he\\ncouldn\u2019t see no sense in the most of it, but he allowed we was white\\nfolks and knowed better than him; so he was satisfied, and said he\\nwould do it all just as Tom said.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T15:28:18Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1847, "name": "Chunk 1847", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "Jim had plenty corn-cob pipes and tobacco; so we had a right down good\\nsociable time; then we crawled out through the hole, and so home to\\nbed, with hands that looked like they\u2019d been chawed. Tom was in high\\nspirits. He said it was the best fun he ever had in his life, and the\\nmost intellectural; and said if he only could see his way to it we\\nwould keep it up all the rest of our lives and leave Jim to our\\nchildren to get out; for he believed Jim would come to like it better\\nand better the more he got used to it. He said that in that way it\\ncould be strung out to as much as eighty year, and would be the best\\ntime on record. And he said it would make us all celebrated that had a\\nhand in it.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 1848, "name": "Chunk 1848", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXVI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass\\ncandlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in\\nhis pocket. Then we went to the nigger cabins, and while I got Nat\u2019s\\nnotice off, Tom shoved a piece of candlestick into the middle of a\\ncorn-pone that was in Jim\u2019s pan, and we went along with Nat to see how\\nit would work, and it just worked noble; when Jim bit into it it most\\nmashed all his teeth out; and there warn\u2019t ever anything could a worked\\nbetter. Tom said so himself. Jim he never let on but what it was only\\njust a piece of rock or something like that that\u2019s always getting into\\nbread, you know; but after that he never bit into nothing but what he\\njabbed his fork into it in three or four places first.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:14Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1849, "name": "Chunk 1849", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "And whilst we was a-standing there in the dimmish light, here comes a\\ncouple of the hounds bulging in from under Jim\u2019s bed; and they kept on\\npiling in till there was eleven of them, and there warn\u2019t hardly room\\nin there to get your breath. By jings, we forgot to fasten that lean-to\\ndoor! The nigger Nat he only just hollered \u201cWitches\u201d once, and keeled\\nover on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was\\ndying. Tom jerked the door open and flung out a slab of Jim\u2019s meat, and\\nthe dogs went for it, and in two seconds he was out himself and back\\nagain and shut the door, and I knowed he\u2019d fixed the other door too.\\nThen he went to work on the nigger, coaxing him and petting him, and\\nasking him if he\u2019d been imagining he saw something again. He raised up,\\nand blinked his eyes around, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:14Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1850, "text": "\u201cMars Sid, you\u2019ll say I\u2019s a fool, but if I didn\u2019t b\u2019lieve I see most a million dogs, er devils, er some\u2019n, I wisht I may die right heah in dese tracks. I did, mos\u2019 sholy. Mars Sid, I _felt_ um\u2014I _felt_ um, sah; dey was all over me. Dad fetch it, I jis\u2019 wisht I could git my han\u2019s on one er dem witches jis\u2019 wunst\u2014on\u2019y jis\u2019 wunst\u2014it\u2019s all _I_\u2019d ast. But mos\u2019ly I wisht dey\u2019d lemme \u2019lone, I does.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1850", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cMars Sid, you\u2019ll say I\u2019s a fool, but if I didn\u2019t b\u2019lieve I see most a\\nmillion dogs, er devils, er some\u2019n, I wisht I may die right heah in\\ndese tracks. I did, mos\u2019 sholy. Mars Sid, I _felt_ um\u2014I _felt_ um, sah;\\ndey was all over me. Dad fetch it, I jis\u2019 wisht I could git my han\u2019s on\\none er dem witches jis\u2019 wunst\u2014on\u2019y jis\u2019 wunst\u2014it\u2019s all _I_\u2019d ast. But\\nmos\u2019ly I wisht dey\u2019d lemme \u2019lone, I does.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:14Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1851, "name": "Tom says:", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "Tom says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:14Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1852, "name": "Chunk 1852", "description": "Text passage in the chapter.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I tell you what _I_ think. What makes them come here just at\\nthis runaway nigger\u2019s breakfast-time? It\u2019s because they\u2019re hungry;\\nthat\u2019s the reason. You make them a witch pie; that\u2019s the thing for\\n_you_ to do.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-20T15:30:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1853, "name": "Chunk 1853", "description": "\u201cBut my lan\u2019, Mars Sid, how\u2019s _I_ gwyne to make \u2019m a witch pie? I doan\u2019 know how to make it. I hain\u2019t ever hearn er sich a thing b\u2019fo.\u201d", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cBut my lan\u2019, Mars Sid, how\u2019s _I_ gwyne to make \u2019m a witch pie? I doan\u2019\\nknow how to make it. I hain\u2019t ever hearn er sich a thing b\u2019fo\u2019.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:15Z"}

{"name": "witch pie", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cBut my lan\u2019, Mars Sid, how\u2019s _I_ gwyne to make \u2019m a witch pie? I doan\u2019\\nknow how to make it. I hain\u2019t ever hearn er sich a thing b\u2019fo\u2019.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1853, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:15Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1854, "text": "\u201cWell, then, I\u2019ll have to make it myself.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1854", "description": "Text passage from the chapter.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then, I\u2019ll have to make it myself.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:15Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1855, "text": "\\\"Will you do it, honey?\u2014will you? I\u2019ll wusshup de groun\u2019 und\u2019 yo\u2019 foot,\\nI will!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"name": "Worship", "description": "The act of wusshup", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cWill you do it, honey?\u2014will you? I\u2019ll wusshup de groun\u2019 und\u2019 yo\u2019 foot,\\nI will!\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1855, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1856, "name": "Chunk 1856", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVI.", "chunk": "\u201cAll right, I\u2019ll do it, seeing it\u2019s you, and you\u2019ve been good to us and\\nshowed us the runaway nigger. But you got to be mighty careful. When we\\ncome around, you turn your back; and then whatever we\u2019ve put in the\\npan, don\u2019t you let on you see it at all. And don\u2019t you look when Jim\\nunloads the pan\u2014something might happen, I don\u2019t know what. And above\\nall, don\u2019t you _handle_ the witch-things.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:15Z"}

And don\u2019t you look when Jim\\nunloads the pan\u2014something might happen, I don\u2019t know what. {"name": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "That was all fixed. So then we went away and went to the rubbage-pile\\nin the back yard, where they keep the old boots, and rags, and pieces\\nof bottles, and wore-out tin things, and all such truck, and scratched\\naround and found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes as well\\nas we could, to bake the pie in, and took it down cellar and stole it\\nfull of flour and started for breakfast, and found a couple of\\nshingle-nails that Tom said would be handy for a prisoner to scrabble\\nhis name and sorrows on the dungeon walls with, and dropped one of them\\nin Aunt Sally\u2019s apron-pocket which was hanging on a chair, and t\u2019other\\nwe stuck in the band of Uncle Silas\u2019s hat, which was on the bureau,\\nbecause we heard the children say their pa and ma was going to the\\nrunaway nigger\u2019s house this morning, and then went to breakfast, and\\nTom dropped the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas\u2019s coat-pocket, and Aunt\\nSally wasn\u2019t come yet, so we had to wait a little while.", "chunk_order_number": 1858, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T00:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1858, "content": "That was all fixed. {"chunk_order_number": 1859, "text": "And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn\u2019t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child\u2019s head with her thimble with the other, and says:", "name": "Chunk 1859", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn\u2019t hardly\\nwait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with\\none hand and cracking the handiest child\u2019s head with her thimble with\\nthe other, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-20T14:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1860, "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve hunted high and I\u2019ve hunted low, and it does beat all what _has_ become of your other shirt.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1860", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cI\u2019ve hunted high and I\u2019ve hunted low, and it does beat all what _has_\\nbecome of your other shirt.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:15Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1861, "name": "Chunk 1861", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "My heart fell down amongst my lungs and livers and things, and a hard\\npiece of corn-crust started down my throat after it and got met on the\\nroad with a cough, and was shot across the table, and took one of the\\nchildren in the eye and curled him up like a fishing-worm, and let a\\ncry out of him the size of a warwhoop, and Tom he turned kinder blue\\naround the gills, and it all amounted to a considerable state of things\\nfor about a quarter of a minute or as much as that, and I would a sold\\nout for half price if there was a bidder. But after that we was all\\nright again\u2014it was the sudden surprise of it that knocked us so kind of\\ncold. Uncle Silas he says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:16Z"}

{"order_number": 1862, "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s most uncommon curious, I can\u2019t understand it. I know perfectly\\nwell I took it _off_, because\u2014\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1862", "description": "Text passage from chapter XXXVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cIt\u2019s most uncommon curious, I can\u2019t understand it. I know perfectly\\nwell I took it _off_, because\u2014\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1862, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T14:20:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1863, "name": "Chunk 1863", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XXXVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cBecause you hain\u2019t got but one _on_. Just _listen_ at the man! _I_\\nknow you took it off, and know it by a better way than your\\nwool-gethering memory, too, because it was on the clo\u2019s-line\\nyesterday\u2014I see it there myself. But it\u2019s gone, that\u2019s the long and the\\nshort of it, and you\u2019ll just have to change to a red flann\u2019l one till I\\ncan get time to make a new one. And it\u2019ll be the third I\u2019ve made in\\ntwo years. It just keeps a body on the jump to keep you in shirts; and\\nwhatever you do manage to _do_ with \u2019m all is more\u2019n _I_ can make out.\\nA body \u2019d think you _would_ learn to take some sort of care of \u2019em at\\nyour time of life.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-26T10:30:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1864, "content": "\\\"I know it, Sally, and I do try all I can. But it oughtn\u2019t to be altogether my fault, because, you know, I don\u2019t see them nor have nothing to do with them except when they\u2019re on me; and I don\u2019t believe I\u2019ve ever lost one of them _off_ of me.\\\"", "name": "Chunk_1864", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cI know it, Sally, and I do try all I can. {"chunk_order_number": 1865, "text": "\u201cWell, it ain\u2019t _your_ fault if you haven\u2019t, Silas; you\u2019d a done it if\\nyou could, I reckon. And the shirt ain\u2019t all that\u2019s gone, nuther.\\nTher\u2019s a spoon gone; and _that_ ain\u2019t all. There was ten, and now\\nther\u2019s only nine. The calf got the shirt, I reckon, but the calf never\\ntook the spoon, _that\u2019s_ certain.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1865", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, it ain\u2019t _your_ fault if you haven\u2019t, Silas; you\u2019d a done it if\\nyou could, I reckon. {"chunk_order_number": 1866, "text": "\u201cWhy, what else is gone, Sally?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1866", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, what else is gone, Sally?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:17Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1867, "text": "\u201cTher\u2019s six _candles_ gone\u2014that\u2019s what. The rats could a got the\\ncandles, and I reckon they did; I wonder they don\u2019t walk off with the\\nwhole place, the way you\u2019re always going to stop their holes and don\u2019t\\ndo it; and if they warn\u2019t fools they\u2019d sleep in your hair,\\nSilas\u2014_you\u2019d_ never find it out; but you can\u2019t lay the _spoon_ on the\\nrats, and that I _know_.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1867", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cTher\u2019s six _candles_ gone\u2014that\u2019s what. {"chunk_order_number": 1885, "name": "Chunk 1885", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole\\nhour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape. Then we heard\\nsteps on the stairs, and blowed out our light and hid; and here comes\\nthe old man, with a candle in one hand and a bundle of stuff in\\nt\u2019other, looking as absent-minded as year before last. He went a\\nmooning around, first to one rat-hole and then another, till he\u2019d been\\nto them all. Then he stood about five minutes, picking tallow-drip off\\nof his candle and thinking. Then he turns off slow and dreamy towards\\nthe stairs, saying:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:19Z"}

{"name": "Aunty", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I\u2019ve counted them twice, Aunty, and _I_ can\u2019t make but nine.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1892, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:20Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1893, "name": "She looked out of all patience, but of course she come to count\u2014anybody would.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "She looked out of all patience, but of course she come to count\u2014anybody\\nwould.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1894, "text": "\\\"I declare to gracious ther\u2019 _ain\u2019t_ but nine!\\\" she says. \\\"Why, what in the world\u2014plague _take_ the things, I\u2019ll count \u2019m again.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1894", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cI declare to gracious ther\u2019 _ain\u2019t_ but nine!\u201d she says. \u201cWhy, what in\\nthe world\u2014plague _take_ the things, I\u2019ll count \u2019m again.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"content": "So I slipped back the one I had, and when she got done counting, she says:", "name": "Chunk 1895", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So I slipped back the one I had, and when she got done counting, she\\nsays:", "chunk_order_number": 1895, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1897, "text": "\u201cWhy, Aunty, _I_ don\u2019t think there\u2019s ten.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1897", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Aunty, _I_ don\u2019t think there\u2019s ten.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1898, "text": "\u201cYou numskull, didn\u2019t you see me _count_ \u2019m?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1898", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cYou numskull, didn\u2019t you see me _count_ \u2019m?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1899, "text": "\\\"I know, but\u2014\\\"", "name": "Chunk 1899", "description": "Text passage from chapter XXXVII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cI know, but\u2014\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:10:10Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 1900", "description": "Text passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I\u2019ll count \u2019m _again_.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1900, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 1901", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So I smouched one, and they come out nine, same as the other time.\\nWell, she _was_ in a tearing way\u2014just a-trembling all over, she was so\\nmad. But she counted and counted till she got that addled she\u2019d start\\nto count in the _basket_ for a spoon sometimes; and so, three times\\nthey come out right, and three times they come out wrong. Then she\\ngrabbed up the basket and slammed it across the house and knocked the\\ncat galley-west; and she said cle\u2019r out and let her have some peace,\\nand if we come bothering around her again betwixt that and dinner she\u2019d\\nskin us. So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket\\nwhilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all\\nright, along with her shingle nail, before noon. We was very well\\nsatisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the\\ntrouble it took, because he said _now_ she couldn\u2019t ever count them\\nspoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn\u2019t believe she\u2019d\\ncounted them right if...", "chunk_order_number": 1901, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"name": "shingle nail", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So I smouched one, and they come out nine, same as the other time.\\nWell, she _was_ in a tearing way\u2014just a-trembling all over, she was so\\nmad. But she counted and counted till she got that addled she\u2019d start\\nto count in the _basket_ for a spoon sometimes; and so, three times\\nthey come out right, and three times they come out wrong. Then she\\ngrabbed up the basket and slammed it across the house and knocked the\\ncat galley-west; and she said cle\u2019r out and let her have some peace,\\nand if we come bothering around her again betwixt that and dinner she\u2019d\\nskin us. So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket\\nwhilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all\\nright, along with her shingle nail, before noon. We was very well\\nsatisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the\\ntrouble it took, because he said _now_ she couldn\u2019t ever count them\\nspoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn\u2019t believe she\u2019d\\ncounted them right if...", "chunk_order_number": 1901, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 1902, "name": "Chunk_1902", "description": "So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn\u2019t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn\u2019t _care_, and warn\u2019t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn\u2019t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of\\nher closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a\\ncouple of days till she didn\u2019t know how many sheets she had any more,\\nand she didn\u2019t _care_, and warn\u2019t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her\\nsoul out about it, and wouldn\u2019t count them again not to save her life;\\nshe druther die first.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1903, "name": "Chunk 1903", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon\\nand the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up\\ncounting; and as to the candlestick, it warn\u2019t no consequence, it would\\nblow over by-and-by.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"name": "calf", "description": "An item", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon\\nand the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up\\ncounting; and as to the candlestick, it warn\u2019t no consequence, it would\\nblow over by-and-by.", "chunk_order_number": 1903, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"name": "candlestick", "description": "An item", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon\\nand the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up\\ncounting; and as to the candlestick, it warn\u2019t no consequence, it would\\nblow over by-and-by.", "chunk_order_number": 1903, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:21Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1904, "name": "Chunk 1904", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "But that pie was a job; we had no end of trouble with that pie. We\\nfixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it\\ndone at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and\\nwe had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through,\\nand we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with\\nthe smoke; because, you see, we didn\u2019t want nothing but a crust, and we\\ncouldn\u2019t prop it up right, and she would always cave in. But of course\\nwe thought of the right way at last\u2014which was to cook the ladder, too,\\nin the pie. So then we laid in with Jim the second night, and tore up\\nthe sheet all in little strings and twisted them together, and long\\nbefore daylight we had a lovely rope that you could a hung a person\\nwith. We let on it took nine months to make it.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T18:58:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1906, "name": "Chunk 1906", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "But we didn\u2019t need it. All we needed was just enough for the pie, and\\nso we throwed the rest away. We didn\u2019t cook none of the pies in the\\nwash-pan\u2014afraid the solder would melt; but Uncle Silas he had a noble\\nbrass warming-pan which he thought considerable of, because it belonged\\nto one of his ancesters with a long wooden handle that come over from\\nEngland with William the Conqueror in the _Mayflower_ or one of them\\nearly ships and was hid away up garret with a lot of other old pots and\\nthings that was valuable, not on account of being any account, because\\nthey warn\u2019t, but on account of them being relicts, you know, and we\\nsnaked her out, private, and took her down there, but she failed on the\\nfirst pies, because we didn\u2019t know how, but she come up smiling on the\\nlast one. {"chunk_order_number": 1907, "name": "Chunk 1907", "description": "Nat didn\u2019t look when we put the witch pie in Jim\u2019s pan; and we put the three tin plates in the bottom of the pan under the vittles; and so Jim got everything all right, and as soon as he was by himself he busted into the pie and hid the rope ladder inside of his straw tick, and scratched some marks on a tin plate and throwed it out of the window-hole.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVII.", "chunk": "Nat didn\u2019t look when we put the witch pie in Jim\u2019s pan; and we put the\\nthree tin plates in the bottom of the pan under the vittles; and so Jim\\ngot everything all right, and as soon as he was by himself he busted\\ninto the pie and hid the rope ladder inside of his straw tick, and\\nscratched some marks on a tin plate and throwed it out of the\\nwindow-hole.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:22Z"}

{"name": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and\\nJim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. {"name": "Chunk 1916", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cOn the scutcheon we\u2019ll have a bend _or_ in the dexter base, a saltire\\n_murrey_ in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and\\nunder his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron _vert_ in\\na chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field _azure_, with\\nthe nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway\\nnigger, _sable_, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister;\\nand a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto,\\n_Maggiore fretta, minore atto._ Got it out of a book\u2014means the more\\nhaste, the less speed.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1916, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T16:40:23Z"}

{"name": "scutcheon", "description": "object", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cOn the scutcheon we\u2019ll have a bend _or_ in the dexter base, a saltire\\n_murrey_ in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and\\nunder his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron _vert_ in\\na chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field _azure_, with\\nthe nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway\\nnigger, _sable_, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister;\\nand a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto,\\n_Maggiore fretta, minore atto._ Got it out of a book\u2014means the more\\nhaste, the less speed.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1916, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T16:40:23Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1931, "name": "Chunk 1931", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "Jim said the rock was worse than the logs; he said it would take him\\nsuch a pison long time to dig them into a rock he wouldn\u2019t ever get\\nout. {"chunk_order_number": 1933, "name": "Chunk 1933", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "It warn\u2019t no slouch of an idea; and it warn\u2019t no slouch of a grindstone\\nnuther; but we allowed we\u2019d tackle it. It warn\u2019t quite midnight yet, so\\nwe cleared out for the mill, leaving Jim at work. We smouched the\\ngrindstone, and set out to roll her home, but it was a most nation\\ntough job. Sometimes, do what we could, we couldn\u2019t keep her from\\nfalling over, and she come mighty near mashing us every time. Tom said\\nshe was going to get one of us, sure, before we got through. We got her\\nhalf way; and then we was plumb played out, and most drownded with\\nsweat. We see it warn\u2019t no use; we got to go and fetch Jim. So he\\nraised up his bed and slid the chain off of the bed-leg, and wrapt it\\nround and round his neck, and we crawled out through our hole and down\\nthere, and Jim and me laid into that grindstone and walked her along\\nlike nothing; and Tom superintended. He could out-superintend any boy I\\never see. He knowed how to do everything.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:25Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1934, "name": "Chunk 1934", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "Our hole was pretty big, but it warn\u2019t big enough to get the grindstone\\nthrough; but Jim he took the pick and soon made it big enough. Then Tom\\nmarked out them things on it with the nail, and set Jim to work on\\nthem, with the nail for a chisel and an iron bolt from the rubbage in\\nthe lean-to for a hammer, and told him to work till the rest of his\\ncandle quit on him, and then he could go to bed, and hide the\\ngrindstone under his straw tick and sleep on it. Then we helped him fix\\nhis chain back on the bed-leg, and was ready for bed ourselves. But Tom\\nthought of something, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:25Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1935, "text": "\\\"You got any spiders in here, Jim?\\\"", "name": "Chunk_1935", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYou got any spiders in here, Jim?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-26T10:00:00Z"}

{"order_number": 1936, "name": "Chunk 1936", "description": "Text chunk from CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cNo, sah, thanks to goodness I hain\u2019t, Mars Tom.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1936, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:26Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1946, "name": "Chunk 1946", "description": "Text content from chapter XXXVIII of ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes\u2014easy enough. Every animal is grateful for kindness and petting,\\nand they wouldn\u2019t _think_ of hurting a person that pets them. Any book\\nwill tell you that. You try\u2014that\u2019s all I ask; just try for two or three\\ndays. Why, you can get him so, in a little while, that he\u2019ll love you;\\nand sleep with you; and won\u2019t stay away from you a minute; and will let\\nyou wrap him round your neck and put his head in your mouth.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:27Z"}

{"name": "animal", "description": "animal mentioned in Chunk 1946", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes\u2014easy enough. You try\u2014that\u2019s all I ask; just try for two or three\\ndays. Why, you can get him so, in a little while, that he\u2019ll love you;\\nand sleep with you; and won\u2019t stay away from you a minute; and will let\\nyou wrap him round your neck and put his head in your mouth.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1946, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:27Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1947, "text": "\u201c_Please_, Mars Tom\u2014_doan_\u2019 talk so! I can\u2019t _stan_\u2019 it! He\u2019d _let_ me shove his head in my mouf\u2014fer a favor, hain\u2019t it? I lay he\u2019d wait a pow\u2019ful long time \u2019fo\u2019 I _ast_ him. {"chunk_order_number": 1950, "content": "\u201cBlame it, can\u2019t you _try?_ I only _want_ you to try\u2014you needn\u2019t keep\\nit up if it don\u2019t work.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1950", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cBlame it, can\u2019t you _try?_ I only _want_ you to try\u2014you needn\u2019t keep\\nit up if it don\u2019t work.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-26T14:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1951, "text": "\u201cBut de trouble all _done_ ef de snake bite me while I\u2019s a tryin\u2019 him. Mars Tom, I\u2019s willin\u2019 to tackle mos\u2019 anything \u2019at ain\u2019t onreasonable, but ef you en Huck fetches a rattlesnake in heah for me to tame, I\u2019s gwyne to _leave_, dat\u2019s _shore_.\u201d", "name": "chunk_1951", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cBut de trouble all _done_ ef de snake bite me while I\u2019s a tryin\u2019 him.\\nMars Tom, I\u2019s willin\u2019 to tackle mos\u2019 anything \u2019at ain\u2019t onreasonable,\\nbut ef you en Huck fetches a rattlesnake in heah for me to tame, I\u2019s\\ngwyne to _leave_, dat\u2019s _shore_.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:28Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1952, "text": "\u201cWell, then, let it go, let it go, if you\u2019re so bull-headed about it.We can get you some garter-snakes, and you can tie some buttons ontheir tails, and let on they\u2019re rattlesnakes, and I reckon that\u2019llhave to do.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1952", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then, let it go, let it go, if you\u2019re so bull-headed about it.\\nWe can get you some garter-snakes, and you can tie some buttons on\\ntheir tails, and let on they\u2019re rattlesnakes, and I reckon that\u2019ll\\nhave to do.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 1957, "text": "\u201cWhy, Mars Tom, I doan\u2019 _want_ no rats. No, sah, gimme g\u2019yarter-snakes, \u2019f I\u2019s got\\nto have \u2019m, but doan\u2019 gimme no rats; I hain\u2019 got no use f\u2019r um,\\nskasely.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1957", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXVIII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Mars Tom, I doan\u2019 _want_ no rats. {"chunk_order_number": 1958, "name": "Chunk_1958", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cBut, Jim, you _got_ to have \u2019em\u2014they all do. So don\u2019t make no more\\nfuss about it. Prisoners ain\u2019t ever without rats. There ain\u2019t no\\ninstance of it. And they train them, and pet them, and learn them\\ntricks, and they get to be as sociable as flies. But you got to play\\nmusic to them. You got anything to play music on?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:29Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1960, "text": "\u201cYes they would. _They_ don\u2019t care what kind of music \u2019tis. A jews-harp\u2019s plenty good enough for a rat. All animals like music\u2014in a prison they dote on it. Specially, painful music; and you can\u2019t get no other kind out of a jews-harp. It always interests them; they come out to see what\u2019s the matter with you. Yes, you\u2019re all right; you\u2019re fixed very well. You want to set on your bed nights before you go to sleep, and early in the mornings, and play your jews-harp; play \u2018The Last Link is Broken\u2019\u2014that\u2019s the thing that\u2019ll scoop a rat quicker \u2019n anything else; and when you\u2019ve played about two minutes you\u2019ll see all the rats, and the snakes, and spiders, and things begin to feel worried about you, and come. And they\u2019ll just fairly swarm over you, and have a noble good time.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1960", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes they would. _They_ don\u2019t care what kind of music \u2019tis. A\\njews-harp\u2019s plenty good enough for a rat. All animals like music\u2014in a\\nprison they dote on it. Specially, painful music; and you can\u2019t get no\\nother kind out of a jews-harp. It always interests them; they come out\\nto see what\u2019s the matter with you. Yes, you\u2019re all right; you\u2019re fixed\\nvery well. You want to set on your bed nights before you go to sleep,\\nand early in the mornings, and play your jews-harp; play \u2018The Last Link\\nis Broken\u2019\u2014that\u2019s the thing that\u2019ll scoop a rat quicker \u2019n anything\\nelse; and when you\u2019ve played about two minutes you\u2019ll see all the rats,\\nand the snakes, and spiders, and things begin to feel worried about\\nyou, and come. And they\u2019ll just fairly swarm over you, and have a noble\\ngood time.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:29Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 1961", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "\u201cYes, _dey_ will, I reck\u2019n, Mars Tom, but what kine er time is _Jim_\\nhavin\u2019? Blest if I kin see de pint. {"name": "onion", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXVIII.", "chunk": "So Tom was stumped. But he studied it over, and then said Jim would\\nhave to worry along the best he could with an onion. He promised he\\nwould go to the nigger cabins and drop one, private, in Jim\u2019s\\ncoffee-pot, in the morning. Jim said he would \u201cjis\u2019 \u2019s soon have\\ntobacker in his coffee;\u201d and found so much fault with it, and with the\\nwork and bother of raising the mullen, and jews-harping the rats, and\\npetting and flattering up the snakes and spiders and things, on top of\\nall the other work he had to do on pens, and inscriptions, and\\njournals, and things, which made it more trouble and worry and\\nresponsibility to be a prisoner than anything he ever undertook, that\\nTom most lost all patience with him; and said he was just loadened down\\nwith more gaudier chances than a prisoner ever had in the world to make\\na name for himself, and yet he didn\u2019t know enough to appreciate them,\\nand they was just about wasted on him. So Jim he was sorry, and said he\\nwouldn\u2019t behave so no more...", "chunk_order_number": 1973, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chapter_number": "39", "name": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "In the morning we went up to the village and bought a wire rat-trap and\\nfetched it down, and unstopped the best rat-hole, and in about an hour\\nwe had fifteen of the bulliest kind of ones; and then we took it and\\nput it in a safe place under Aunt Sally\u2019s bed. But while we was gone\\nfor spiders little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps\\nfound it there, and opened the door of it to see if the rats would come\\nout, and they did; and Aunt Sally she come in, and when we got back she\\nwas a-standing on top of the bed raising Cain, and the rats was doing\\nwhat they could to keep off the dull times for her. So she took and\\ndusted us both with the hickry, and we was as much as two hours\\ncatching another fifteen or sixteen, drat that meddlesome cub, and they\\nwarn\u2019t the likeliest, nuther, because the first haul was the pick of\\nthe flock. I never see a likelier lot of rats than what that first haul\\nwas.", "chunk_order_number": 1974, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-10-27T16:40:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1975, "name": "Chunk 1975", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "We got a splendid stock of sorted spiders, and bugs, and frogs, and\\ncaterpillars, and one thing or another; and we like to got a hornet\u2019s\\nnest, but we didn\u2019t. The family was at home. We didn\u2019t give it right\\nup, but stayed with them as long as we could; because we allowed we\u2019d\\ntire them out or they\u2019d got to tire us out, and they done it. Then we\\ngot allycumpain and rubbed on the places, and was pretty near all right\\nagain, but couldn\u2019t set down convenient. And so we went for the snakes,\\nand grabbed a couple of dozen garters and house-snakes, and put them in\\na bag, and put it in our room, and by that time it was supper-time, and\\na rattling good honest day\u2019s work: and hungry?\u2014oh, no, I reckon not!\\nAnd there warn\u2019t a blessed snake up there when we went back\u2014we didn\u2019t\\nhalf tie the sack, and they worked out somehow, and left. But it didn\u2019t\\nmatter much, because they was still on the premises somewheres. So we\\njudged we could get some of them again. No, there warn\u2019t no real\\nsc...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-03T18:06:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1976, "name": "Chunk 1976", "description": "Text segment from chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "We got a licking every time one of our snakes come in her way, and she\\nallowed these lickings warn\u2019t nothing to what she would do if we ever\\nloaded up the place again with them. I didn\u2019t mind the lickings,\\nbecause they didn\u2019t amount to nothing; but I minded the trouble we had\\nto lay in another lot. But we got them laid in, and all the other\\nthings; and you never see a cabin as blithesome as Jim\u2019s was when\\nthey\u2019d all swarm out for music and go for him. Jim didn\u2019t like the\\nspiders, and the spiders didn\u2019t like Jim; and so they\u2019d lay for him,\\nand make it mighty warm for him. And he said that between the rats and\\nthe snakes and the grindstone there warn\u2019t no room in bed for him,\\nskasely; and when there was, a body couldn\u2019t sleep, it was so lively,\\nand it was always lively, he said, because _they_ never all slept at\\none time, but took turn about, so when the snakes was asleep the rats\\nwas on deck, and when the rats turned in the snakes come on watch, so\\nhe always had one gan...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T13:48:32Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1977, "name": "Chunk_1977", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "Well, by the end of three weeks everything was in pretty good shape.\\nThe shirt was sent in early, in a pie, and every time a rat bit Jim he\\nwould get up and write a little in his journal whilst the ink was\\nfresh; the pens was made, the inscriptions and so on was all carved on\\nthe grindstone; the bed-leg was sawed in two, and we had et up the\\nsawdust, and it give us a most amazing stomach-ache. We reckoned we was\\nall going to die, but didn\u2019t. It was the most undigestible sawdust I\\never see; and Tom said the same.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:30Z"}

{"name": "Chunk_1978", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "But as I was saying, we\u2019d got all the work done now, at last; and we\\nwas all pretty much fagged out, too, but mainly Jim. The old man had\\nwrote a couple of times to the plantation below Orleans to come and get\\ntheir runaway nigger, but hadn\u2019t got no answer, because there warn\u2019t no\\nsuch plantation; so he allowed he would advertise Jim in the St. Louis\\nand New Orleans papers; and when he mentioned the St. Louis ones it\\ngive me the cold shivers, and I see we hadn\u2019t no time to lose. So Tom\\nsaid, now for the nonnamous letters.", "chunk_order_number": 1978, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1979, "name": "Chunk 1979", "description": "\u201cWhat\u2019s them?\u201d I says.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cWhat\u2019s them?\u201d I says.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:31Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1980, "name": "Chunk_1980", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cWarnings to the people that something is up. Sometimes it\u2019s done one\\nway, sometimes another. But there\u2019s always somebody spying around that\\ngives notice to the governor of the castle. When Louis XVI. was going\\nto light out of the Tooleries, a servant-girl done it. It\u2019s a very good\\nway, and so is the nonnamous letters. We\u2019ll use them both. And it\u2019s\\nusual for the prisoner\u2019s mother to change clothes with him, and she\\nstays in, and he slides out in her clothes. We\u2019ll do that, too.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:31Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1982, "name": "Chunk_1982", "description": "\u201cYes, I know; but you can\u2019t depend on them. {"name": "Chunk 1985", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cBut I ain\u2019t going to make no complaint. Any way that suits you suits\\nme. {"order_number": 1986, "text": "\u201cYou\u2019ll be her.
