{"order_number": 1987, "text": "\u201cWhy, Tom, that\u2019ll make trouble next morning; because, of course, she prob\u2019bly hain\u2019t got any but that one.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1987", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, Tom, that\u2019ll make trouble next morning; because, of course, she\\nprob\u2019bly hain\u2019t got any but that one.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1987, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:32Z"}

{"order_number": 1988, "name": "Chunk_1988", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cI know; but you don\u2019t want it but fifteen minutes, to carry the\\nnonnamous letter and shove it under the front door.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1988, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T12:00:00Z"}

{"order_number": 1989, "text": "\u201cAll right, then, I\u2019ll do it; but I could carry it just as handy in my\\nown togs.\u201d", "name": "Chunk 1989", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cAll right, then, I\u2019ll do it; but I could carry it just as handy in my\\nown togs.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 1989, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:33Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1990, "name": "Chunk 1990", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cYou wouldn\u2019t look like a servant-girl _then_, would you?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T12:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1991, "name": "Chunk 1991", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XXXIX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cNo, but there won\u2019t be nobody to see what I look like, _anyway_.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:33Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 1996, "name": "Chunk 1996", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXIX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "\u201cNot much. I\u2019ll stuff Jim\u2019s clothes full of straw and lay it on his bed\\nto represent his mother in disguise, and Jim \u2019ll take the nigger\\nwoman\u2019s gown off of me and wear it, and we\u2019ll all evade together. When\\na prisoner of style escapes it\u2019s called an evasion. It\u2019s always called\\nso when a king escapes, f\u2019rinstance. {"chunk_order_number": 1999, "name": "Chunk 1999", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XXXIX", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "Next night we stuck a picture, which Tom drawed in blood, of a skull\\nand crossbones on the front door; and next night another one of a\\ncoffin on the back door. I never see a family in such a sweat. They\\ncouldn\u2019t a been worse scared if the place had a been full of ghosts\\nlaying for them behind everything and under the beds and shivering\\nthrough the air. If a door banged, Aunt Sally she jumped and said\\n\u201couch!\u201d if anything fell, she jumped and said \u201couch!\u201d if you happened\\nto touch her, when she warn\u2019t noticing, she done the same; she couldn\u2019t\\nface noway and be satisfied, because she allowed there was something\\nbehind her every time\u2014so she was always a-whirling around sudden, and\\nsaying \u201couch,\u201d and before she\u2019d got two-thirds around she\u2019d whirl back\\nagain, and say it again; and she was afraid to go to bed, but she\\ndasn\u2019t set up. So the thing was working very well, Tom said; he said he\\nnever see a thing work more satisfactory. He said it showed it was done\\nright.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:34Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2001, "name": "Don\u2019t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of cutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your runaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as you will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang, but have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life again, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from northards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go in the nigger\u2019s cabin to get him. I am to be off a piece and blow a tin horn if I see any danger; but stead of that I will BA like a sheep soon as they get in and not blow at all; then whilst they are getting his chains loose, you slip there and lock them in, and can kill them at your leasure. Don\u2019t do anything but just the way I am telling you, if you do they will suspicion something and raise whoop-jamboreehoo. I do not wish any reward but to know I have done the right thing.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "Don\u2019t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of\\ncutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your\\nrunaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as\\nyou will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang,\\nbut have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life\\nagain, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from\\nnorthards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go\\nin the nigger\u2019s cabin to get him. {"name": "cutthroats", "chapter": "CHAPTER XXXIX.", "chunk": "Don\u2019t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of\\ncutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your\\nrunaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as\\nyou will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang,\\nbut have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life\\nagain, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from\\nnorthards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go\\nin the nigger\u2019s cabin to get him. {"name": "CHAPTER XL.", "description": "Chapter in ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "We was feeling pretty good after breakfast, and took my canoe and went\\nover the river a-fishing, with a lunch, and had a good time, and took a\\nlook at the raft and found her all right, and got home late to supper,\\nand found them in such a sweat and worry they didn\u2019t know which end\\nthey was standing on, and made us go right off to bed the minute we was\\ndone supper, and wouldn\u2019t tell us what the trouble was, and never let\\non a word about the new letter, but didn\u2019t need to, because we knowed\\nas much about it as anybody did, and as soon as we was half up stairs\\nand her back was turned we slid for the cellar cupboard and loaded up a\\ngood lunch and took it up to our room and went to bed, and got up about\\nhalf-past eleven, and Tom put on Aunt Sally\u2019s dress that he stole and\\nwas going to start with the lunch, but says:", "chunk_order_number": 2003, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}

{"chunk_order_number": 2008, "content": "\u201cWe can get along _with_ it, too,\u201d he says; \u201cjust you slide down cellar\\nand fetch it. {"chunk_order_number": 2009, "name": "Chunk_2009", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "So out he went, and down cellar went I. The hunk of butter, big as a\\nperson\u2019s fist, was where I had left it, so I took up the slab of\\ncorn-pone with it on, and blowed out my light, and started up stairs\\nvery stealthy, and got up to the main floor all right, but here comes\\nAunt Sally with a candle, and I clapped the truck in my hat, and\\nclapped my hat on my head, and the next second she see me; and she\\nsays:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:35Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2019, "name": "Chunk 2019", "description": "\u201cI hain\u2019t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if\\nI have.\u201d", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "\u201cI hain\u2019t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if\\nI have.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:36Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2020, "name": "Chunk 2020", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XL", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "I reckoned she\u2019d let me go now, and as a generl thing she would; but I\\ns\u2019pose there was so many strange things going on she was just in a\\nsweat about every little thing that warn\u2019t yard-stick straight; so she\\nsays, very decided:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "Something", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "\u201cYou just march into that setting-room and stay there till I come. You\\nbeen up to something you no business to, and I lay I\u2019ll find out what\\nit is before _I\u2019m_ done with you.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 2021, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "setting-room", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "So she went away as I opened the door and walked into the setting-room.\\nMy, but there was a crowd there! Fifteen farmers, and every one of them\\nhad a gun. I was most powerful sick, and slunk to a chair and set down.\\nThey was setting around, some of them talking a little, in a low voice,\\nand all of them fidgety and uneasy, but trying to look like they\\nwarn\u2019t; but I knowed they was, because they was always taking off their\\nhats, and putting them on, and scratching their heads, and changing\\ntheir seats, and fumbling with their buttons. I warn\u2019t easy myself, but\\nI didn\u2019t take my hat off, all the same.", "chunk_order_number": 2022, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "The Narrator", "description": "Narrator of the text", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "I did wish Aunt Sally would come, and get done with me, and lick me, if\\nshe wanted to, and let me get away and tell Tom how we\u2019d overdone this\\nthing, and what a thundering hornet\u2019s-nest we\u2019d got ourselves into, so\\nwe could stop fooling around straight off, and clear out with Jim\\nbefore these rips got out of patience and come for us.", "chunk_order_number": 2023, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "Men", "description": "Group of men", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I _couldn\u2019t_ answer\\nthem straight, I didn\u2019t know which end of me was up; because these men\\nwas in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right _now_ and\\nlay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn\u2019t but a few minutes to\\nmidnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the\\nsheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me\\na-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that\\nscared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter\\nbeginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty\\nsoon, when one of them says, \u201c_I\u2019m_ for going and getting in the cabin\\n_first_ and right _now_, and catching them when they come,\u201d I most\\ndropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and\\nAunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:", "chunk_order_number": 2024, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "Butter", "description": "Object mentioned in the passage", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I _couldn\u2019t_ answer\\nthem straight, I didn\u2019t know which end of me was up; because these men\\nwas in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right _now_ and\\nlay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn\u2019t but a few minutes to\\nmidnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the\\nsheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me\\na-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that\\nscared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter\\nbeginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty\\nsoon, when one of them says, \u201c_I\u2019m_ for going and getting in the cabin\\n_first_ and right _now_, and catching them when they come,\u201d I most\\ndropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and\\nAunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:", "chunk_order_number": 2024, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:37Z"}

{"name": "the lean-to", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "I was up stairs in a second, and down the lightning-rod in another one,\\nand shinning through the dark for the lean-to. {"chunk_order_number": 2049, "name": "Chunk 2049", "description": "Text passage from chapter XL.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "I knowed he was white inside, and I reckoned he\u2019d say what he did\\nsay\u2014so it was all right now, and I told Tom I was a-going for a doctor.\\nHe raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and\\nwouldn\u2019t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose\\nhimself; but we wouldn\u2019t let him. Then he give us a piece of his mind,\\nbut it didn\u2019t do no good.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-07-27T13:15:10Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2050, "text": "So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:", "name": "Chunk 2050", "description": "Text segment of CHAPTER XL.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:40Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2051, "name": "Chunk 2051", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XL.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XL.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, then, if you\u2019re bound to go, I\u2019ll tell you the way to do when\\nyou get to the village. Shut the door and blindfold the doctor tight\\nand fast, and make him swear to be silent as the grave, and put a purse\\nfull of gold in his hand, and then take and lead him all around the\\nback alleys and everywheres in the dark, and then fetch him here in the\\ncanoe, in a roundabout way amongst the islands, and search him and take\\nhis chalk away from him, and don\u2019t give it back to him till you get him\\nback to the village, or else he will chalk this raft so he can find it\\nagain. It\u2019s the way they all do.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:40Z"}

{"name": "CHAPTER XLI.", "description": "Chapter 41 of the book", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got\\nhim up. I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting\\nyesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and\\nabout midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off\\nand shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it\\nand not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted\\nto come home this evening and surprise the folks.", "chunk_order_number": 2053, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2065, "text": "But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he\u2019d look around for a bigger one. But I said I didn\u2019t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.", "name": "Chunk 2065", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head,\\nand said he reckoned he\u2019d look around for a bigger one. {"chunk_order_number": 2066, "name": "Chunk 2066", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "I struck an idea pretty soon. I says to myself, spos\u2019n he can\u2019t fix\\nthat leg just in three shakes of a sheep\u2019s tail, as the saying is?\\nspos\u2019n it takes him three or four days? What are we going to do?\u2014lay\\naround there till he lets the cat out of the bag? No, sir; I know what\\n_I\u2019ll_ do. I\u2019ll wait, and when he comes back if he says he\u2019s got to go\\nany more I\u2019ll get down there, too, if I swim; and we\u2019ll take and tie\\nhim, and keep him, and shove out down the river; and when Tom\u2019s done\\nwith him we\u2019ll give him what it\u2019s worth, or all we got, and then let\\nhim get ashore.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T15:30:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2067, "name": "Chunk 2067", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XLI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "So then I crept into a lumber-pile to get some sleep; and next time I\\nwaked up the sun was away up over my head! I shot out and went for the\\ndoctor\u2019s house, but they told me he\u2019d gone away in the night some time\\nor other, and warn\u2019t back yet. Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad\\nfor Tom, and I\u2019ll dig out for the island right off. So away I shoved,\\nand turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas\u2019s\\nstomach! He says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:42Z"}

{"name": "doctor\u2019s house", "description": "A location", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "So then I crept into a lumber-pile to get some sleep; and next time I\\nwaked up the sun was away up over my head! I shot out and went for the\\ndoctor\u2019s house, but they told me he\u2019d gone away in the night some time\\nor other, and warn\u2019t back yet. Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad\\nfor Tom, and I\u2019ll dig out for the island right off. So away I shoved,\\nand turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas\u2019s\\nstomach! He says:", "chunk_order_number": 2067, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:42Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2071, "name": "Chunk 2071", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cShe needn\u2019t,\u201d I says, \u201cbecause we was all right. We followed the men\\nand the dogs, but they outrun us, and we lost them; but we thought we\\nheard them on the water, so we got a canoe and took out after them and\\ncrossed over, but couldn\u2019t find nothing of them; so we cruised along\\nup-shore till we got kind of tired and beat out; and tied up the canoe\\nand went to sleep, and never waked up till about an hour ago; then we\\npaddled over here to hear the news, and Sid\u2019s at the post-office to see\\nwhat he can hear, and I\u2019m a-branching out to get something to eat for\\nus, and then we\u2019re going home.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:43Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2072, "text": "So then we went to the post-office to get \u201cSid\u201d; but just as I\\nsuspicioned, he warn\u2019t there; so the old man he got a letter out of the\\noffice, and we waited a while longer, but Sid didn\u2019t come; so the old\\nman said, come along, let Sid foot it home, or canoe it, when he got\\ndone fooling around\u2014but we would ride. {"chunk_order_number": 2075, "name": "Chunk 2075", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, Sister Phelps, I\u2019ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an\u2019 I b\u2019lieve\\nthe nigger was crazy. I says to Sister Damrell\u2014didn\u2019t I, Sister\\nDamrell?\u2014s\u2019I, he\u2019s crazy, s\u2019I\u2014them\u2019s the very words I said. You all\\nhearn me: he\u2019s crazy, s\u2019I; everything shows it, s\u2019I. Look at that-air\\ngrindstone, s\u2019I; want to tell _me_\u2019t any cretur \u2019t\u2019s in his right mind\\n\u2019s a goin\u2019 to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s\u2019I?\\nHere sich \u2019n\u2019 sich a person busted his heart; \u2019n\u2019 here so \u2019n\u2019 so pegged\\nalong for thirty-seven year, \u2019n\u2019 all that\u2014natcherl son o\u2019 Louis\\nsomebody, \u2019n\u2019 sich everlast\u2019n rubbage. He\u2019s plumb crazy, s\u2019I; it\u2019s what\\nI says in the fust place, it\u2019s what I says in the middle, \u2019n\u2019 it\u2019s what\\nI says last \u2019n\u2019 all the time\u2014the nigger\u2019s crazy\u2014crazy \u2019s\\nNebokoodneezer, s\u2019I.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:43Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2079, "name": "Chunk 2079", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cMy very _words_, Brer Penrod! {"chunk_order_number": 2081, "name": "Chunk 2081", "description": "\u201cYou may _well_ say it, Brer Hightower! It\u2019s jist as I was a-sayin\u2019 to Brer Phelps, his own self. S\u2019e, what do _you_ think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s\u2019e? Think o\u2019 what, Brer Phelps, s\u2019I? Think o\u2019 that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s\u2019e? _think_ of it, s\u2019I? I lay it never sawed _itself_ off, s\u2019I\u2014somebody _sawed_ it, s\u2019I; that\u2019s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn\u2019t be no \u2019count, s\u2019I, but sich as \u2019t is, it\u2019s my opinion, s\u2019I, \u2019n\u2019 if any body k\u2019n start a better one, s\u2019I, let him _do_ it, s\u2019I, that\u2019s all. {"chunk_order_number": 2082, "name": "Chunk 2082", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cWhy, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o\u2019 niggers in there\\nevery night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps. Look\\nat that shirt\u2014every last inch of it kivered over with secret African\\nwrit\u2019n done with blood! Must a ben a raft uv \u2019m at it right along, all\\nthe time, amost. Why, I\u2019d give two dollars to have it read to me; \u2019n\u2019\\nas for the niggers that wrote it, I \u2019low I\u2019d take \u2019n\u2019 lash \u2019m t\u2019ll\u2014\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:44Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2083, "name": "Chunk 2083", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cPeople to _help_ him, Brother Marples! Well, I reckon you\u2019d _think_ so\\nif you\u2019d a been in this house for a while back. Why, they\u2019ve stole\\neverything they could lay their hands on\u2014and we a-watching all the\\ntime, mind you. They stole that shirt right off o\u2019 the line! and as for\\nthat sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther\u2019 ain\u2019t no telling how\\nmany times they _didn\u2019t_ steal that; and flour, and candles, and\\ncandlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand\\nthings that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and\\nSilas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day _and_ night, as I\\nwas a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor\\nsight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold\\nyou, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only\\nfools _us_ but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets _away_\\nwith that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and\\ntwenty-two dogs right ...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:44Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2088, "text": "\u201cGoodnessgracioussakes, I\u2019d a ben afeard to _live_ in sich a\u2014\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2088", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XLI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201cGoodnessgracioussakes, I\u2019d a ben afeard to _live_ in sich a\u2014\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:45Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 2089", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "\u201c\u2019Fraid to _live!_\u2014why, I was that scared I dasn\u2019t hardly go to bed, or\\nget up, or lay down, or _set_ down, Sister Ridgeway. Why, they\u2019d steal\\nthe very\u2014why, goodness sakes, you can guess what kind of a fluster _I_\\nwas in by the time midnight come last night. I hope to gracious if I\\nwarn\u2019t afraid they\u2019d steal some o\u2019 the family! I was just to that pass\\nI didn\u2019t have no reasoning faculties no more. It looks foolish enough\\n_now_, in the daytime; but I says to myself, there\u2019s my two poor boys\\nasleep, \u2019way up stairs in that lonesome room, and I declare to goodness\\nI was that uneasy \u2019t I crep\u2019 up there and locked \u2019em in! I _did_. And\\nanybody would. Because, you know, when you get scared that way, and it\\nkeeps running on, and getting worse and worse all the time, and your\\nwits gets to addling, and you get to doing all sorts o\u2019 wild things,\\nand by-and-by you think to yourself, spos\u2019n _I_ was a boy, and was away\\nup there, and the door ain\u2019t locked, and you\u2014\u201d She stopped, looking...", "chunk_order_number": 2089, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:45Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2097, "name": "Chunk 2097", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLI", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "And then when I went up to bed she come up with me and fetched her\\ncandle, and tucked me in, and mothered me so good I felt mean, and like\\nI couldn\u2019t look her in the face; and she set down on the bed and talked\\nwith me a long time, and said what a splendid boy Sid was, and didn\u2019t\\nseem to want to ever stop talking about him; and kept asking me every\\nnow and then if I reckoned he could a got lost, or hurt, or maybe\\ndrownded, and might be laying at this minute somewheres suffering or\\ndead, and she not by him to help him, and so the tears would drip down\\nsilent, and I would tell her that Sid was all right, and would be home\\nin the morning, sure; and she would squeeze my hand, or maybe kiss me,\\nand tell me to say it again, and keep on saying it, because it done her\\ngood, and she was in so much trouble. And when she was going away she\\nlooked down in my eyes so steady and gentle, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:46Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2100, "name": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI.", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLI. of ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLI.", "chunk": "But she was on my mind and Tom was on my mind, so I slept very\\nrestless. And twice I went down the rod away in the night, and slipped\\naround front, and see her setting there by her candle in the window\\nwith her eyes towards the road and the tears in them; and I wished I\\ncould do something for her, but I couldn\u2019t, only to swear that I\\nwouldn\u2019t never do nothing to grieve her any more. And the third time I\\nwaked up at dawn, and slid down, and she was there yet, and her candle\\nwas most out, and her old gray head was resting on her hand, and she\\nwas asleep.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:46Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 2109", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn\u2019t stir. But\\nbefore she could break it open she dropped it and run\u2014for she see\\nsomething. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old\\ndoctor; and Jim, in _her_ calico dress, with his hands tied behind him;\\nand a lot of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that come\\nhandy, and rushed. {"chunk_order_number": 2113, "name": "Chunk_2113", "description": "Text segment from chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the\\nold doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house. The men\\nwas very huffy, and some of them wanted to hang Jim for an example to\\nall the other niggers around there, so they wouldn\u2019t be trying to run\\naway like Jim done, and making such a raft of trouble, and keeping a\\nwhole family scared most to death for days and nights. But the others\\nsaid, don\u2019t do it, it wouldn\u2019t answer at all; he ain\u2019t our nigger, and\\nhis owner would turn up and make us pay for him, sure. So that cooled\\nthem down a little, because the people that\u2019s always the most anxious\\nfor to hang a nigger that hain\u2019t done just right is always the very\\nones that ain\u2019t the most anxious to pay for him when they\u2019ve got their\\nsatisfaction out of him.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:48Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2114, "name": "Text chunk", "description": "A segment of text from chapter XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "They cussed Jim considerble, though, and give him a cuff or two side\\nthe head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let\\non to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own\\nclothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time,\\nbut to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands,\\ntoo, and both legs, and said he warn\u2019t to have nothing but bread and\\nwater to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction\\nbecause he didn\u2019t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our\\nhole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around\\nabout the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the\\ndaytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was\\ntapering off with a kind of generl good-bye cussing, and then the old\\ndoctor comes and takes a look, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:48Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2115, "name": "Chunk 2115", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cDon\u2019t be no rougher on him than you\u2019re obleeged to, because he ain\u2019t a\\nbad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn\u2019t cut\\nthe bullet out without some help, and he warn\u2019t in no condition for me\\nto leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little\\nworse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn\u2019t let\\nme come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he\u2019d kill\\nme, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn\u2019t do\\nanything at all with him; so I says, I got to have _help_ somehow; and\\nthe minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says\\nhe\u2019ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course I\\njudged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I _was!_ and there I had\\nto stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night. It\\nwas a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and\\nof course I\u2019d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn\u2019t,\\nb...", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:48Z"}

{"order_number": 2117, "text": "\\\"Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I\u2019m obleeged to say.\\\"", "name": "Chunk 2117", "description": "Text segment", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, it sounds very good, doctor, I\u2019m obleeged to say.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 2117, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2118, "name": "Chunk 2118", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Then the others softened up a little, too, and I was mighty thankful to\\nthat old doctor for doing Jim that good turn; and I was glad it was\\naccording to my judgment of him, too; because I thought he had a good\\nheart in him and was a good man the first time I see him. Then they all\\nagreed that Jim had acted very well, and was deserving to have some\\nnotice took of it, and reward. So every one of them promised, right out\\nand hearty, that they wouldn\u2019t cuss him no more.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:20:30Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2119, "name": "Chunk 2119", "description": "Text passage from chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Then they come out and locked him up. I hoped they was going to say he\\ncould have one or two of the chains took off, because they was rotten\\nheavy, or could have meat and greens with his bread and water; but they\\ndidn\u2019t think of it, and I reckoned it warn\u2019t best for me to mix in, but\\nI judged I\u2019d get the doctor\u2019s yarn to Aunt Sally somehow or other as\\nsoon as I\u2019d got through the breakers that was laying just ahead of\\nme\u2014explanations, I mean, of how I forgot to mention about Sid being\\nshot when I was telling how him and me put in that dratted night\\npaddling around hunting the runaway nigger.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:49Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2121, "name": "Chunk 2121", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt\\nSally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I\\nfound him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that\\nwould wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and\\npale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and\\nlaid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding\\nin, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and\\nset down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful\\nnow, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he\u2019d been sleeping\\nlike that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the\\ntime, and ten to one he\u2019d wake up in his right mind.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:49Z"}

{"name": "yarn", "description": "Story", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt\\nSally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I\\nfound him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that\\nwould wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and\\npale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and\\nlaid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding\\nin, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and\\nset down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful\\nnow, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he\u2019d been sleeping\\nlike that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the\\ntime, and ten to one he\u2019d wake up in his right mind.", "chunk_order_number": 2121, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:49Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 2126", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cThe same,\u201d I says, but couldn\u2019t say it pretty brash. {"chunk_order_number": 2127, "name": "Chunk 2127", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cGood! Splendid! _Now_ we\u2019re all right and safe! {"chunk_order_number": 2133, "name": "Chunk 2133", "description": "Text segment from chapter XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201c_No_, I ain\u2019t out of my HEAD; I know all what I\u2019m talking about. We\\n_did_ set him free\u2014me and Tom. {"chunk_order_number": 2135, "name": "Chunk 2135", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201c\u2014and load up the cabin with rats and snakes and so on, for company for\\nJim; and then you kept Tom here so long with the butter in his hat that\\nyou come near spiling the whole business, because the men come before\\nwe was out of the cabin, and we had to rush, and they heard us and let\\ndrive at us, and I got my share, and we dodged out of the path and let\\nthem go by, and when the dogs come they warn\u2019t interested in us, but\\nwent for the most noise, and we got our canoe, and made for the raft,\\nand was all safe, and Jim was a free man, and we done it all by\\nourselves, and _wasn\u2019t_ it bully, Aunty!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-20T10:31:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2136, "name": "Chunk 2136", "description": "Text segment of the book", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was\\n_you_, you little rapscallions, that\u2019s been making all this trouble,\\nand turned everybody\u2019s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to\\ndeath. I\u2019ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o\u2019\\nyou this very minute. To think, here I\u2019ve been, night after night,\\na\u2014_you_ just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I\u2019ll tan the Old\\nHarry out o\u2019 both o\u2019 ye!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:50Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2137, "content": "But Tom, he _was_ so proud and joyful, he just _couldn\u2019t_ hold in, and his tongue just _went_ it\u2014she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:", "name": "Chunk 2137", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "But Tom, he _was_ so proud and joyful, he just _couldn\u2019t_ hold in, and\\nhis tongue just _went_ it\u2014she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all\\nalong, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and\\nshe says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:51Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2138, "text": "\u201c_Well_, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it _now_, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again\u2014\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2138", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201c_Well_, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it _now_, for mind I\\ntell you if I catch you meddling with him again\u2014\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:51Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2139, "name": "Chunk 2139", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cMeddling with _who?_\u201d Tom says, dropping his smile and looking\\nsurprised.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:51Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2140, "content": "\u201cWith _who?_ Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who\u2019d you reckon?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2140", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWith _who?_ Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who\u2019d you reckon?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:51Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2141, "name": "Chunk 2141", "description": "Tom looks at me very grave, and says:", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Tom looks at me very grave, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-08-08T12:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2143, "text": "\\\"_Him?_\\\" says Aunt Sally; \\\"the runaway nigger? 'Deed he hasn't. They've got him back, safe and sound, and he's in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he's claimed or sold!\\\"", "name": "Chunk 2143", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201c_Him?_\u201d says Aunt Sally; \u201cthe runaway nigger? \u2019Deed he hasn\u2019t. They\u2019ve\\ngot him back, safe and sound, and he\u2019s in that cabin again, on bread\\nand water, and loaded down with chains, till he\u2019s claimed or sold!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T10:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2144, "text": "Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:", "name": "Chunk 2144", "description": "Text segment from Chapter XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening\\nand shutting like gills, and sings out to me:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2145, "text": "\u201cThey hain\u2019t no _right_ to shut him up! _Shove!_\u2014and don\u2019t you lose a\\nminute. Turn him loose! he ain\u2019t no slave; he\u2019s as free as any cretur\\nthat walks this earth!\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2145", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cThey hain\u2019t no _right_ to shut him up! _Shove!_\u2014and don\u2019t you lose a\\nminute. Turn him loose! he ain\u2019t no slave; he\u2019s as free as any cretur\\nthat walks this earth!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T12:30:00Z"}

{"name": "Chunk 2146", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWhat _does_ the child mean?\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 2146, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"name": "Ashamed", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cI mean every word I _say_, Aunt Sally, and if somebody don\u2019t go,\\n_I\u2019ll_ go. I\u2019ve knowed him all his life, and so has Tom, there. Old\\nMiss Watson died two months ago, and she was ashamed she ever was going\\nto sell him down the river, and _said_ so; and she set him free in her\\nwill.\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 2147, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2148, "text": "\u201cThen what on earth did _you_ want to set him free for, seeing he was already free?\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2148", "description": "Text passage from chapter XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cThen what on earth did _you_ want to set him free for, seeing he was\\nalready free?\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2149, "text": "\u201cWell, that _is_ a question, I must say; and _just_ like women! Why, I\\nwanted the _adventure_ of it; and I\u2019d a waded neck-deep in blood\\nto\u2014goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!\u201d", "name": "Chunk 2149", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, that _is_ a question, I must say; and _just_ like women! Why, I\\nwanted the _adventure_ of it; and I\u2019d a waded neck-deep in blood\\nto\u2014goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"name": "AUNT POLLY", "description": "Character in ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cWell, that _is_ a question, I must say; and _just_ like women! Why, I\\nwanted the _adventure_ of it; and I\u2019d a waded neck-deep in blood\\nto\u2014goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!\u201d", "chunk_order_number": 2149, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:52Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2150, "text": "If she warn\u2019t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as sweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!", "name": "Chunk 2150", "description": "Text passage from the chapter", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "If she warn\u2019t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as\\nsweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-20T12:34:56Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2156, "name": "Chunk 2156", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Aunt Sally she was one of the mixed-upest-looking persons I ever\\nsee\u2014except one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he come in and they told\\nit all to him. {"chunk_order_number": 2157, "text": "And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn\u2019t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he _could_ help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.", "name": "Chunk 2157", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting\\nJim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took\\nall that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn\u2019t\\never understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he _could_\\nhelp a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T12:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2158, "text": "Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and _Sid_ had come all right and safe, she says to herself:", "name": "Chunk 2158", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom\\nand _Sid_ had come all right and safe, she says to herself:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:54Z"}

{"order_number": 2159, "name": "Chunk 2159", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cLook at that, now! {"name": "evasion", "description": "Event in the story", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "The first time I catched Tom private I asked him what was his idea,\\ntime of the evasion?\u2014what it was he\u2019d planned to do if the evasion\\nworked all right and he managed to set a nigger free that was already\\nfree before? And he said, what he had planned in his head from the\\nstart, if we got Jim out all safe, was for us to run him down the river\\non the raft, and have adventures plumb to the mouth of the river, and\\nthen tell him about his being free, and take him back up home on a\\nsteamboat, in style, and pay him for his lost time, and write word\\nahead and get out all the niggers around, and have them waltz him into\\ntown with a torchlight procession and a brass-band, and then he would\\nbe a hero, and so would we. But I reckoned it was about as well the way\\nit was.", "chunk_order_number": 2174, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-11-02T18:46:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2175, "text": "We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom, they made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him all he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do. And we had him up to the sick-room, and had a high talk; and Tom give Jim forty dollars for being prisoner for us so patient, and doing it up so good, and Jim was pleased most to death, and busted out, and says:", "name": "Chunk_2175", "description": "Text segment from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle\\nSilas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom,\\nthey made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him\\nall he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do. And we had\\nhim up to the sick-room, and had a high talk; and Tom give Jim forty\\ndollars for being prisoner for us so patient, and doing it up so good,\\nand Jim was pleased most to death, and busted out, and says:", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-10-27T15:00:00Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2176, "name": "Chunk 2176", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201c_Dah_, now, Huck, what I tell you?\u2014what I tell you up dah on Jackson\\nislan\u2019? I _tole_ you I got a hairy breas\u2019, en what\u2019s de sign un it; en\\nI _tole_ you I ben rich wunst, en gwineter to be rich _agin;_ en it\u2019s\\ncome true; en heah she _is! Dah_, now! doan\u2019 talk to _me_\u2014signs is\\n_signs_, mine I tell you; en I knowed jis\u2019 \u2019s well \u2019at I \u2019uz gwineter\\nbe rich agin as I\u2019s a-stannin\u2019 heah dis minute!\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:57Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2177, "text": "And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le\u2019s all three slide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a couple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I ain\u2019t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn\u2019t get none from home, because it\u2019s likely pap\u2019s been back before now, and got it all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up.", "name": "Chunk 2177", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le\u2019s all three\\nslide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for\\nhowling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a\\ncouple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I\\nain\u2019t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn\u2019t get\\nnone from home, because it\u2019s likely pap\u2019s been back before now, and got\\nit all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up.", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2025-06-01T16:40:57Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2178, "name": "Chunk 3", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cNo, he hain\u2019t,\u201d Tom says; \u201cit\u2019s all there yet\u2014six thousand dollars and\\nmore; and your pap hain\u2019t ever been back since. Hadn\u2019t when I come\\naway, anyhow.\u201d", "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0, "timestamp": "2024-05-03T14:45:12Z"}

{"chunk_order_number": 2185, "name": "Chunk 2185", "description": "Text passage from CHAPTER XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "\u201cDoan\u2019 you \u2019member de house dat was float\u2019n down de river, en dey wuz a\\nman in dah, kivered up, en I went in en unkivered him and didn\u2019 let you\\ncome in? {"name": "Chunk_2186", "description": "Text passage from Chapter XLII.", "chapter": "CHAPTER XLII.", "chunk": "Tom\u2019s most well now, and got his bullet around his neck on a\\nwatch-guard for a watch, and is always seeing what time it is, and so\\nthere ain\u2019t nothing more to write about, and I am rotten glad of it,\\nbecause if I\u2019d a knowed what a trouble it was to make a book I wouldn\u2019t\\na tackled it, and ain\u2019t a-going to no more. But I reckon I got to light\\nout for the Territory ahead of the rest, because Aunt Sally she\u2019s going\\nto adopt me and sivilize me, and I can\u2019t stand it. I been there before.", "chunk_order_number": 2186, "author": "Mark Twain", "book": "ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN", "chunk_index": 0}
